revision.text:
A '''corporate integrity agreement''' (CIA) is a document outlining the obligations that a company involved in [[health care in the United States]] makes with a federal government agency or a state government as part of a [[Settlement (litigation)|civil settlement]]. On the federal level the [[United_States_Department_of_Health_and_Human_Services#Office_of_Inspector_General|Office of Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services]] and the [[Department of Justice]] are usually involved, and on the state level, the [[state attorney general]] and the state offices involved in [[Medicaid]] or [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] are involved.<ref name=OIGFAQ>{{cite web|title=Corporate Integrity Agreement FAQ|url=https://oig.hhs.gov/faqs/corporate-integrity-agreements-faq.asp|publisher=Office of Inspector General, Department of Health and Human Services|accessdate=14 April 2018|language=en}}</ref>
CIA can be used to address [[Health care quality|quality of care]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Quality of Care: Corporate Integrity Agreements|url=https://oig.hhs.gov/compliance/corporate-integrity-agreements/quality-of-care.asp|publisher=Office of Inspector General, Department of Health and Human Services|accessdate=14 April 2018|language=en}}</ref> or [[Corporate governance|corporate integrity]] issues.<ref name=OIGFAQ/>
CIAs create a framework within which the company must operate in order to avoid being barred from participation in federal health care programs.<ref name=OIGFAQ/> States use CIAs as part of their anti-fraud efforts.<ref>{{cite web|title=Press release: Attorney General’s Office Agrees To Settlement And Corporate Integrity Agreement With Keene Medical Products On Medicaid Fraud Investigation|url=http://ago.vermont.gov/focus/news/attorney-generals-office-agrees-to-settlement-and-corporate-integrity-agreement-with-keene-medical-products-on-medicaid-fraud-investigation.php|publisher=Vermont Office of the Attorney General|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161223202110/http://ago.vermont.gov/focus/news/attorney-generals-office-agrees-to-settlement-and-corporate-integrity-agreement-with-keene-medical-products-on-medicaid-fraud-investigation.php|archivedate=23 December 2016|date=9 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Redacted Corporate Integrity Agreement between the New York State Office of the Medicaid Inspector General and Ralex Services, Inc|url=https://omig.ny.gov/images/stories/cia/20160401_Glen_Island_CIA_Fully_Executed%20CIA_Redacted.pdf|publisher=New York State Office of the Medicaid Inspector General|accessdate=14 April 2018|language=en-gb|date=April 2016}}</ref>{{rp|9}}
CIAs generally last 5 years. During this time the provider is usually required to implement or expand a comprehensive employee training program, a confidential disclosure program, written standards and policies, and designate a compliance officer and committee if these things are not already done.<ref>{{cite web|title=Corporate Integrity Agreements|url=https://oig.hhs.gov/compliance/corporate-integrity-agreements/index.asp|publisher=Office of Inspector General, Department of Health and Human Services|accessdate=14 April 2018|language=en}}</ref> CIAs also mandate establishing processes for managing and reporting “reportable events.” Reportable events include overpayments, ongoing investigations or legal proceedings, potential violation of criminal, civil, or administrative laws applicable to any Federal health care program for which penalties or exclusion may be authorized, and employing or contracting with an ineligible person.<ref name=OIGFAQ/>
Some CIAs require an independent organization to review and monitor compliance with the terms and conditions of the CIA. Most CIAs require claims reviews to identify errors and their underlying causes.<ref name=OIGFAQ/> The government agency may check compliance through site visits.<ref name=OIGFAQ/> If a company breaks the agreement, the agency can fine them and if issues cannot be resolved the provider may be barred.<ref>{{cite web|title=Corporate Integrity Agreement Enforcement|url=https://oig.hhs.gov/fraud/enforcement/ciae/index.asp|publisher=Office of Inspector General, Department of Health and Human Services|accessdate=14 April 2018|language=en}}</ref>
==References== {{HHS content|url=https://www.cms.gov/Medicare-Medicaid-Coordination/Fraud-Prevention/Medicaid-Integrity-Education/Downloads/ebulletins-corporateintegrity-agreement.pdf|title = Corporate Integrity Agreements Snapshot|accessdate=14 April 2018}} {{reflist}}
[[Category:American legal terminology]] [[Category:Health law in the United States]] [[Category:Medicare and Medicaid (United States)]]

'''Disease management''' is defined as "a system of coordinated [[healthcare]] interventions and communications for populations with conditions in which patient [[self-care]] efforts are significant."<ref>Care Continuum Alliance. [http://www.carecontinuum.org/dm_definition.asp Care Continuum Alliance (CCA) definition of disease management.] Retrieved 2011-05-24.</ref><ref name=CBO>Congressional Budget Office. [http://www.cbo.gov/ftpdocs/59xx/doc5909/10-13-DiseaseMngmnt.pdf An analysis of the literature on disease management programs.] 2004-10-13. Retrieved 2008-10-13.</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Coughlin JF, etal | date = Apr 2006 | title = Old age, new technology, and future innovations in disease management and home health care | url = http://web.mit.edu/agelab/news_events/pdfs/home.health.care.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Home Health Care Management & Practice | volume = 18 | issue = 3| pages = 196–207 | doi=10.1177/1084822305281955}}</ref>
For people who can access health care practitioners or peer support it is the process whereby persons with long-term conditions (and often family/friend/carer) share knowledge, responsibility and care plans with healthcare practitioners and/or peers. To be effective it requires whole system implementation with community social support networks, a range of satisfying occupations and activities relevant to the context, clinical professionals willing to act as partners or coaches and on-line resources which are verified and relevant to the country and context. Knowledge sharing, [[knowledge building]] and a learning community are integral to the concept of disease management. It is a population health strategy as well as an approach to personal health. It may reduce healthcare costs and/or improve [[quality of life]] for individuals by preventing or minimizing the effects of [[disease]], usually a [[Chronic (medical)|chronic]] condition, through knowledge, skills, enabling a sense of control over life (despite symptoms of disease) and integrative care. On the other hand, it may increase health care costs by causing high implementation costs and promoting the use of costly health care interventions.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Gandjour |first1=Afschin |title=A model to predict the cost-effectiveness of disease management programs |journal=Health Economics |date=2010 |volume=19 |issue=6 |pages=697-715 |doi=10.1002/hec.1503}}</ref>
==History== Disease management has evolved from [[managed care]], specialty capitation, and health service [[demand management]], and refers to the processes and people concerned with improving or maintaining health in large populations. It is concerned with common [[chronic (medicine)|chronic]] illnesses, and the reduction of future complications associated with those diseases.
Illnesses that disease management would concern itself with would include: [[coronary heart disease]], [[chronic obstructive pulmonary disease]] (COPD), [[kidney failure]], [[hypertension]], [[heart failure]], [[obesity]], [[diabetes mellitus]], [[asthma]], [[cancer]], [[arthritis]], [[clinical depression]], [[sleep apnea]], [[osteoporosis]], and other common ailments.
==Industry==
In the United States, disease management is a large industry with many vendors. Major disease management organizations based on revenues and other criteria<ref name=HIRC>[http://hirc.com/files/public/Update_Dis_Mgmt_su08.pdf Leading disease management organizations.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081118064758/http://hirc.com/files/public/Update_Dis_Mgmt_su08.pdf |date=November 18, 2008 }} Santa Cruz, CA: Health Industries Research Companies, 2008 Summer. Retrieved 2008-12-16.</ref><ref name=Matheson>Matheson D, et al. [http://www.bcg.com/publications/files/Realizing_the_Promise_of_Disease_Management_Feb06.pdf Realizing the promise of disease management. Payer trends and opportunities in the United States.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070202094237/http://www.bcg.com/publications/files/Realizing_the_Promise_of_Disease_Management_Feb06.pdf |date=February 2, 2007 }} Boston: Boston Consulting Group, 2006 February. Retrieved 2008-12-16.</ref> include Accordant (a subsidiary of Caremark), Alere (now including ParadigmHealth and Matria Healthcare),<ref>Alere. [http://www.alere.com/alerehealth/history.html History.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519054005/http://www.alere.com/alerehealth/history.html |date=May 19, 2011 }} Retrieved 2011-05-23.</ref> Caremark (excluding its Accordant subsidiary), Evercare, [[Health Dialog]], [[Healthways]], LifeMasters (now part of StayWell), LifeSynch (formerly Corphealth),<ref>[https://archive.is/20120914151514/http://www.humana.com/providers/newsletters/HumanaWeb4thQ08/articles/two.html Corphealth Changes Brand Name to LifeSynch.] Humana's Your Practice, 2008 Fourth Quarter. Retrieved 2009-07-15.</ref> Magellan, McKesson Health Solutions, and MedAssurant.
Disease management is of particular importance to [[health plan]]s, agencies, trusts, associations and [[employer]]s that offer [[health insurance]]. A 2002 survey found that 99.5% of enrollees of [[Health Maintenance Organization]]/[[Point of service plan|Point Of Service]] (HMO/POS) plans are in plans that cover at least one disease management program.<ref>America’s Health Insurance Plans. [http://www.ahip.org/content/default.aspx?bc=38|82|2244 2002 AHIP survey of health insurance plans: chart book of findings.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050206084343/http://www.ahip.org/content/default.aspx?bc=38 |date=February 6, 2005 }} Washington, DC: AHIP, 2004 April. Retrieved 2008-12-04.</ref> A [[Mercer (consulting firms)|Mercer Consulting]] study indicated that the percentage of employer-sponsored health plans offering disease management programs grew to 58% in 2003, up from 41% in 2002.<ref name=Landro>Landro L. [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB109822237688649826 Does disease management pay off?] ''Wall Street Journal'', October 20, 2004.</ref>
It was reported that $85 million was spent on disease management in the United States in 1997, and $600 million in 2002.<ref name=Lau>Lau G. [https://archive.is/20130126174851/http://www.investors.com/NewsAndAnalysis/Article/412296/200909140811/Study-Questions-Effectiveness-Of-Disease-Management-At-Issue-Cost-Savings-Study-reviewer-says-not-all-programs-get-proper-return-on-investment.aspx Study questions' effectiveness of disease management.] ''Investor's Business Daily'', 2005-10-03.</ref> Between 2000 and 2005, the compound annual growth rate of revenues for disease management organizations was 28%.<ref name=Matheson/> In 2000, the [[Boston Consulting Group]] estimated that the U.S. market for outsourced disease management could be $20 billion by 2010;<ref name=Matheson/> however, in 2008 the Disease Management Purchasing Consortium estimated that disease management organization revenues would be $2.8 billion by 2010.<ref name=HIRC/> As of 2010, a study using National Ambulatory Medical Care Survey data estimated that 21.3% of patients in the U.S. with at least one chronic condition use disease management programs.<ref>{{Cite journal | title = National estimates of enrollment in disease management programs in the United States: an analysis of the National Ambulatory Medical Care Survey data | journal = Popul Health Manag | volume = 13 | pages = 183–88 | year = 2010 | doi = 10.1089/pop.2009.0056 | pmid = 20735245 |vauthors=Kalsekar I, etal | issue = 4 }}</ref> Yet, management of chronic conditions is responsible for more than 75% of all health care spending.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality | url=https://innovations.ahrq.gov/perspectives/chronic-disease-management-can-reduce-readmissions |title=Chronic Disease Management Can Reduce Readmissions: A Conversation With Jack Meyer, PhD, Managing Principal, Health Management Associates |date=2013-04-17 |accessdate=2013-10-17}}</ref>
== Process == The underlying premise of disease management is that when the right tools, experts, and equipment are applied to a population, labor costs (specifically: absenteeism, presenteeism, and direct insurance expenses) can be minimized in the near term, or resources can be provided more efficiently. The general idea is to ease the disease path, rather than cure the disease. Improving quality and activities for daily living are first and foremost. Improving cost, in some programs, is a necessary component, as well. However, some disease management systems believe that reductions in longer term problems may not be measureable today, but may warrant continuation of disease management programs until better data is available in 10–20 years. Most disease management vendors offer [[return on investment]] (ROI) for their programs, although over the years there have been dozens of ways to measure ROI. Responding to this inconsistency, an industry trade association, the [[Care Continuum Alliance]], convened industry leaders to develop consensus guidelines for measuring clinical and financial outcomes in disease management, wellness and other population-based programs. Contributing to the work were public and private health and quality organizations, including the federal [[Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality]], the [[National Committee for Quality Assurance]], [[URAC]], and the [[Joint Commission]]. The project produced the first volume of a now four-volume Outcomes Guidelines Report, which details industry-consensus approaches to measuring outcomes.
Tools include web-based assessment tools, clinical guidelines, health risk assessments, outbound and inbound call-center-based triage, best practices, formularies, and numerous other devices, systems and protocols.
Experts include [[actuary|actuaries]], [[physician]]s, [[pharmacist]]s, [[economist|medical economists]], [[nurse]]s, [[nutritionist]]s, [[physical therapist]]s, [[statistician]]s, [[epidemiologist]]s, and [[human resources|human resources professionals]]. Equipment can include mailing systems, web-based applications (with or without interactive modes), monitoring devices, or telephonic systems.
==Effectiveness==
===Possible biases=== When disease management programs are voluntary, studies of their effectiveness may be affected by a [[self-selection bias]]; that is, a program may "attract enrollees who were [already] highly motivated to succeed".<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kominski GF, etal | date = Mar 2008 | title = The effect of disease management on utilization of services by race/ethnicity: evidence from the Florida Medicaid program | url = http://www.ajmc.com/media/pdf/AJMC_08marKominski_168to172.pdf | format = PDF | journal = American Journal of Managed Care | volume = 14 | issue = 3 | pages = 168–72 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110721213630/http://www.ajmc.com/media/pdf/AJMC_08marKominski_168to172.pdf | archivedate = 2011-07-21 | df = | pmid = 18333709 }}</ref> At least two studies have found that people who enroll in disease management programs differ significantly from those who do not on baseline clinical, demographic, cost, utilization and quality parameters.<ref name="Buntin-2009">{{Cite journal | title = Who Gets Disease Management? | journal = J Gen Intern Med | volume = 24 | pages = 649–55 | year = 2009 | doi = 10.1007/s11606-009-0950-8 | pmid=19308336 | pmc = 2669874 |vauthors=Buntin MB, etal | issue = 5}}</ref><ref name="Schäfer-2010">{{Cite journal | title = Selection effects may account for better outcomes of the German Disease Management Program for type 2 diabetes | journal = BMC Health Serv Res | volume = 10 | pages = 351 | year = 2010 | doi = 10.1186/1472-6963-10-351 | pmid = 21194442 | url = http://www.biomedcentral.com/1472-6963/10/351 |vauthors=Schäfer I, etal | pmc = 3023779}}</ref> To minimize any bias in estimates of the effectiveness of disease management due to differences in baseline characteristics, [[randomized controlled trial]]s are better than [[observational study|observational studies]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Linden A, etal | date = Apr 2006 | title = Strengthening the case for disease management effectiveness: un-hiding the hidden bias | url = http://www.lindenconsulting.org/documents/HiddenBias_Print.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Journal of Evaluation in Clinical Practice | volume = 12 | issue = 2| pages = 140–47 | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2753.2005.00612.x| pmid = 16579822 }}</ref>
Even if a particular study is a randomized trial, it may not provide strong evidence for the effectiveness of disease management. A 2009 review paper examined randomized trials and meta-analyses of disease management programs for heart failure and asserted that many failed the [[PICO process]] and [[Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials]]: "interventions and comparisons are not sufficiently well described; that complex programs have been excessively oversimplified; and that potentially salient differences in programs, populations, and settings are not incorporated into analyses."<ref name="Clark-2009">{{Cite journal | title = What is the strength of evidence for heart failure disease-management programs? | journal = J Am Coll Cardiol | volume = 54 | pages = 397–401 | year = 2009 | doi = 10.1016/j.jacc.2009.04.051 | pmid = 19628113 | url = http://content.onlinejacc.org/cgi/content/full/54/5/397 | issue=5 |vauthors=Clark AM, etal }}</ref>
===Medicare===
Section 721 of the [[Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act]] of 2003 authorized the [[Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services]] (CMS) to conduct what became the "Medicare Health Support" project to examine disease management.<ref name=CMSMHS>Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. [http://www.cms.hhs.gov/CCIP/04_RegionalPrograms.asp Medicare Health Support. Regional programs.] 2008-09-26. Retrieved 2008-12-07.</ref> Phase I of the project involved disease management companies (such as [[Aetna]] Health Management, [[Cigna|CIGNA]] Health Support, Health Dialog Services Corp., Healthways, and McKesson Health Solutions) chosen by a competitive process in eight states and the District of Columbia.<ref name=CMSMHS/> The project focused on people with diabetes or heart failure who had relatively high Medicare payments; in each location, approximately 20,000 such people were randomly assigned to an intervention group and 10,000 were randomly assigned to a control group.<ref name=McCall2007>McCall N, et al. [http://www.cms.hhs.gov/reports/downloads/McCall.pdf Evaluation of Phase I of Medicare Health Support (Formerly Voluntary Chronic Care Improvement) pilot program under traditional fee-for-service Medicare.] Report to Congress. 2007 June. Retrieved 2008-12-07.</ref> CMS set goals in the areas of clinical quality and beneficiary satisfaction, and negotiated with the disease management programs for a target of 5% savings in Medicare costs.<ref name=CMSfact>Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. [http://www.cms.hhs.gov/CCIP/downloads/EOP_Fact_Sheet_FINAL_012808.pdf Fact sheet. Completion of Phase I of Medicare Health Support Program.] 2008-01-28. Retrieved 2008-12-07.</ref> The programs started between August 2005 and January 2006.<ref name=CMSMHS/> What is now the Care Continuum Alliance praised the project as "the first-ever national pilot integrating sophisticated care management techniques into the Medicare fee-for-service program".<ref>Disease Management Association of America (DMAA). [http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/releases/37119.php Medicare Health Support off to 'outstanding' start, Disease Management Association hails program's progress, US.] 2006-02-03. Retrieved 2011-05-23.</ref>
An initial evaluation of Phase I of the project by [[RTI International]] appeared in June 2007 which had "three key participation and financial findings":<ref name=McCall2007/> * Medicare expenditures for the intervention group were higher than those of the comparison group by the time the pilots started. * Within the intervention group, participants had lower Medicare payments (i.e., tended to be healthier) than non-participants. * The "fees paid to date far exceed any savings produced." DMAA focused on another finding of the initial evaluation, the "high levels of satisfaction with chronic disease management services among beneficiaries and physicians".<ref>Moorhead, Tracey. [https://web.archive.org/web/20080706163936/http://www.dmaa.org/news_releases/2007/pressrelease_070607.asp DMAA statement on Medicare Health Support report to Congress.] 2007-07-06. Retrieved 2011-05-23.</ref> One commentary noted that the project "can only be observational" since "equivalence was not achieved at baseline".<ref>Wilson T. [http://www.dmalliance.org/dmblog/2007/07/national-expert-critiques-mhs-initial.html National expert critiques MHS initial analysis. A critique of baseline issues in the initial Medicare Health Support report.] ''Disease Management Viewpoints'' blog, 2007-07-18. Retrieved 2008-12-07.</ref> Another commentary claimed that the project was "in big trouble".<ref>Wilson T, Kuraitis V. [http://e-caremanagement.com/disease-management-and-the-medicare-health-support-mhs-project-houston-we-have-a-problem/ Disease management and the Medicare Health Support (MHS) Project: "Houston, we have a problem."] ''e-CareManagement'' blog, 2007-09-06. Retrieved 2008-12-07.</ref> A paper on the six-month evaluation, published in fall 2008, concluded that "Results to date indicate limited success in achieving Medicare cost savings or reducing acute care utilization".<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Cromwell J, etal | date = Fall 2008 | title = Evaluation of Medicare Health Support chronic disease pilot program | url = http://www.cms.hhs.gov/HealthCareFinancingReview/downloads/08Fallpg47.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Health Care Financing Review | volume = 30 | issue = 1| pages = 47–60 | pmid = 19040173 | pmc = 4195046 }}</ref>
In December 2007, CMS changed the financial threshold from 5% savings to budget neutrality, a change that DMAA "hailed".<ref name=CMSfact/><ref>DMAA: The Care Continuum Alliance. [https://web.archive.org/web/20080706163427/http://www.dmaa.org/news_releases/2008/pressrelease_010808.asp DMAA hails decision on financial threshold for Medicare Health Support.] 2008-01-08. Retrieved 2011-05-23.</ref> In January 2008, however, CMS decided to end Phase I because it claimed that the statutory authority had run out.<ref>Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. [http://www.cms.hhs.gov/CCIP/downloads/MHSEOPexfaqsfin012808_FINAL.pdf Completion of Phase I of Medicare Health Support program. FAQs.] 2008-01-29. Retrieved 2008-12-07.</ref> Four U.S. senators wrote a letter to CMS to reverse its decision.<ref>DoBias M. [http://www.modernhealthcare.com/article/20080317/REG/64622388 Senators press CMS on disease-management pilot program.] ''Modern Healthcare'', 2008-03-17.</ref> DMAA decried the termination of Phase I and called upon CMS to start Phase II as soon as possible.<ref>Moorhead T. [http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/releases/95682.php Statement on CMS announcement regarding Phase I of Medicare Health Support – DMAA: The Care Continuum Alliance.] 2008-01-30. Retrieved 2011-05-23.</ref><ref>Moorhead T. [http://www.modernhealthcare.com/article/20080324/SUB/177457105 Don't fly off handle after a pilot test. Feds, private sector must not abandon the promise of disease management.] ''Modern Healthcare'', 2008-03-24.</ref> Among other criticisms of the project, the disease management companies claimed that Medicare "signed up patients who were much sicker than they had expected," failed to transmit information on patients' prescriptions and laboratory results to them in a timely fashion, and disallowed the companies from selecting patients most likely to benefit from disease management.<ref name=Abelson>Abelson R. [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/07/business/07medicare.html Medicare finds how hard it is to save money.] ''New York Times'', 2008-04-07. Retrieved 2008-12-07.</ref>
By April 2008, CMS had spent $360 million on the project.<ref name=Abelson/> The individual programs ended between December 2006 and August 2008.<ref name=CMSMHS/>
The results of the program were published in ''[[The New England Journal of Medicine]]'' in November 2011.<ref name="McCall-2011">{{Cite journal |vauthors=McCall N, Cromwell J | title = Results of the Medicare Health Support disease-management pilot program | journal = N Engl J Med | volume = 365 | issue = 18 | pages = 1704–12 | year = 2011 | doi = 10.1056/NEJMsa1011785 | pmid = 22047561 }}</ref> Comparing the 163,107 patients randomized to the intervention group with the 79,310 patients randomized to the control group, the researchers found that "disease-management programs did not reduce hospital admissions or emergency room visits, as compared with usual care."<ref name="McCall-2011"/> Furthermore, there was "no demonstrable savings in Medicare expenditures," with the [[Net (economics)|net]] fees for disease management ranging from 3.8% to 10.9% per patient per month.<ref name="McCall-2011"/> The researchers suggested that the findings might be explained by the severity of chronic disease among the patients studied, delays in patients' receiving disease management after hospitalizations, and lack of integration between health coaches and the patients' primary care providers.<ref name="McCall-2011"/><ref>{{cite news |title=Disease management program fails to cut Medicare costs |author=Moon MA |url= http://www.familypracticenews.com/news/more-top-news/single-view/disease-management-program-fails-to-cut-medicare-costs/a350524c59.html |newspaper=Family Practice News Digital Network |date=2011-11-02 |accessdate=2011-11-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Medicare pilot fails to cut costs or boost quality|author=Gever G |url= http://www.medpagetoday.com/PublicHealthPolicy/Medicare/29457 |newspaper=MedPage Today |date=2011-11-04 |accessdate=2011-11-07}}</ref>
===Other studies=== Studies that have reviewed other studies on the effectiveness of disease management include the following: * A 2004 [[Congressional Budget Office]] analysis concluded that published studies "do not provide a firm basis for concluding that disease management programs generally reduce total costs".<ref name=CBO/> The report caused the disease management industry to "scrambl[e] to build a better business case for their services".<ref name=Benko>Benko LB. [http://modernhealthcare.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070115/SUB/70112004 Payers and purchasers: numbers that count. Disease-management industry is taking steps to deliver more reliability, consistency in data on program outcomes.] ''[[Modern Healthcare]]'', 2007-01-15.</ref> * A 2005 review of 44 studies on disease management found a positive [[Rate of return|return on investment]] (ROI) for congestive heart failure and multiple disease conditions, but inconclusive, mixed, or negative ROI for diabetes, asthma, and depression management programs.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Goetzel | first1 = RZ |date=Summer 2005 | title = Return on investment in disease management: a review | url = http://www.cms.hhs.gov/HealthCareFinancingReview/downloads/05summerpg1.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Health Care Financing Review | volume = 26 | issue = 4| pages = 1–19 | pmid = 17288065 | last2 = Ozminkowski | first2 = RJ | last3 = Villagra | first3 = VG | last4 = Duffy | first4 = J }}</ref> The lead author, of [[Cornell University]] and [[Thomson Healthcare|Thomson]] Medstat, was quoted as saying that the paucity of research conducted on the ROI of disease management was "a concern because so many companies and government agencies have adopted disease management to manage the cost of care for people with chronic conditions."<ref name=Lau/> * A 2007 [[RAND]] summary of 26 reviews and meta-analyses of small-scale disease management programs, and 3 evaluations of population-based disease management programs, concluded that "Payers and policy makers should remain skeptical about vendor claims [concerning disease management] and should demand supporting evidence based on transparent and scientifically sound methods."<ref name=Mattke>{{cite journal | last1 = Mattke | first1 = S | date = Dec 2007 | title = Evidence for the effect of disease management: is $1 billion a year a good investment? | url = http://www.ajmc.com/media/pdf/AJMC_07dec_Mattke_670to76.pdf | format = PDF | journal = American Journal of Managed Care | volume = 13 | issue = 12 | pages = 670–76 | pmid = 18069910 | last2 = Seid | first2 = M | last3 = Ma | first3 = S | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110721213644/http://www.ajmc.com/media/pdf/AJMC_07dec_Mattke_670to76.pdf | archivedate = 2011-07-21 | df = }}</ref> In specific: ** Disease management improved "clinical processes of care" (e.g., adherence to evidence-based guidelines) for congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, diabetes, and depression. ** There was inconclusive evidence, insufficient evidence, or evidence for no effect of disease management on health-related behaviors. ** Disease management led to better disease control for congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, diabetes, and depression. ** There was inconclusive evidence, insufficient evidence, or evidence for no effect of disease management on clinical outcomes (e.g., "mortality and functional status"). ** Disease management reduced hospital admission rates for congestive heart failure, but increased health care utilization for depression, with inconclusive or insufficient evidence for the other diseases studied. ** In the area of financial outcomes, there was inconclusive evidence, insufficient evidence, evidence for no effect, or evidence for increased costs. ** Disease management increased patient satisfaction and health-related quality of life in congestive heart failure and depression, but the evidence was insufficient for the other diseases studied. :A subsequent letter to the editor claimed that disease management might nevertheless "satisfy buyers today, even if academics remain unconvinced".<ref>Norman GK. [http://www.ajmc.com/media/pdf/AJMC_08jan_WebLetter_Norman.pdf All things considered, the answer is a resounding yes.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721213649/http://www.ajmc.com/media/pdf/AJMC_08jan_WebLetter_Norman.pdf |date=July 21, 2011 }} ''American Journal of Managed Care'' 2008 Jan;14:e2-e4. Retrieved 2008-12-06.</ref> * A 2008 systematic review and meta-analysis concluded that disease management for COPD "modestly improved exercise capacity, health-related quality of life, and hospital admissions, but not all-cause mortality".<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Peytremann-Bridevaux I, etal | date = May 2008 | title = Effectiveness of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease-management programs: systematic review and meta-analysis | url = http://www.amjmed.com/article/S0002-9343(08)00177-0/abstract | journal = American Journal of Medicine | volume = 121 | issue = 5| pages = 433–43 | doi=10.1016/j.amjmed.2008.02.009}}</ref> * A 2009 review of 27 studies "could not draw definitive conclusions about the effectiveness or cost-effectiveness of... asthma disease-management programs" for adults.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Adult asthma disease management: an analysis of studies, approaches, outcomes, and methods | url = http://www.rcjournal.com/contents/07.09/07.09.0878.pdf | journal = Respir Care | volume = 54 | pages = 878–86 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19558739 | issue=7 |vauthors=Maciejewski ML, etal | doi = 10.4187/002013209793800385}}</ref> * A Canadian systematic review published in 2009 found that home [[telehealth]] in chronic disease management may be cost-saving but that "the quality of the studies was generally low."<ref>{{Cite journal | title = Home telehealth for chronic disease management: a systematic review and an analysis of economic evaluations | journal = Int J Technol Assess Health Care | volume = 25 | issue = 3 | pages = 339–49 | year = 2009 | doi = 10.1017/S0266462309990201 | pmid = 19619353 |vauthors=Polisena J, etal }}</ref> * Researchers from The Netherlands systematically reviewed 31 papers published 2007–09 and determined that the evidence that disease management programs for four diseases reduce healthcare expenditures is "inconclusive."<ref>{{Cite journal | title = Impact of disease management programs on healthcare expenditures for patients with diabetes, depression, heart failure or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: a systematic review of the literature | journal = Health Policy | volume = 101| issue = 2| pages = 105–21|date=May 2011 | doi = 10.1016/j.healthpol.2011.03.006 | pmid = 21592607 |vauthors=de Bruin SR, etal }}</ref> * A meta-analysis of randomized trials published through 2009 estimated that disease management for diabetes has "a clinically moderate but significant impact on [[Glycated hemoglobin|hemoglobin A<sub>1C</sub>]] levels," with an absolute mean difference of 0.51% between experimental and control groups.<ref name="Pimouguet-2011">{{Cite journal | title = Effectiveness of disease-management programs for improving diabetes care: a meta-analysis | journal = CMAJ | volume = 183 | pages = E115–27 | year = 2011 | doi = 10.1503/cmaj.091786 | pmid = 21149524 | url = http://www.cmaj.ca/cgi/content/full/183/2/E115 | issue=2 |vauthors=Pimouguet C, etal | pmc = 3033953}}</ref> * A 2011 "meta-review" (systematic review of meta-analyses) of heart failure disease management programs found them to be of "mixed quality" in that they did not report important characteristics of the studies reviewed.<ref name="Savard-2011">{{Cite journal |vauthors=Savard LA, Thompson DR, Clark AM | title = A meta-review of evidence on heart failure disease management programs: the challenges of describing and synthesizing evidence on complex interventions | journal = Trials | volume = 12 | issue = 1 | pages = 194 |date=Aug 2011 | doi = 10.1186/1745-6215-12-194 | pmid = 21846340 | pmc=3174117}}</ref>
Recent studies not reviewed in the aforementioned papers include the following: * A U.K. study published in 2007 found certain improvements in the care of patients with coronary artery disease and heart failure (e.g., better management of blood pressure and cholesterol) if they received nurse-led disease management instead of usual care.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Khunti K, etal | year = 2007 | title = Disease management programme for secondary prevention of coronary heart disease and heart failure in primary care: a cluster randomised controlled trial | url = http://heart.bmj.com/cgi/content/full/93/11/1398 | journal = Heart | volume = 93 | issue = 11| pages = 1398–405 | doi=10.1136/hrt.2006.106955| pmid = 17309907 | pmc = 2016933 }}</ref> * In a 2007 Canadian study, people were randomized to receive or not receive disease management for heart failure for a period of six months. [[Emergency department]] visits, hospital readmissions, and all-cause deaths were no different in the two groups after 2.8 years of follow-up.<ref name="Nguyen-2007">{{Cite journal | title = Lack of long-term benefits of a 6-month heart failure disease management program | journal = J Card Fail | volume = 13 | pages = 287–93 | year = 2007 | doi = 10.1016/j.cardfail.2007.01.002 | pmid = 17517349 |vauthors=Nguyen V, etal | issue = 4 }}</ref> * A 2008 U.S. study found that nurse-led disease management for patients with heart failure was "reasonably [[Cost-effectiveness analysis|cost-effective]]" per [[quality-adjusted life year]] compared with a "usual care group".<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Hebert PL, etal | year = 2008 | title = Cost-effectiveness of nurse-led disease management for heart failure in an ethnically diverse urban community | url = http://annals.org/cgi/content/abstract/149/8/540 | journal = Annals of Internal Medicine | volume = 149 | issue = 8| pages = 540–48 | doi=10.7326/0003-4819-149-8-200810210-00006| pmid = 18936502 | pmc = 4312002 }}</ref> * A 2008 study from the Netherlands compared no disease management with "basic" nurse-led disease management with "intensive" nurse-led disease management for patients discharged from the hospital with heart failure; it detected no significant differences in hospitalization and death for the three groups of patients.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Jaarsma T, etal | year = 2008 | title = Effect of moderate or intensive disease management program on outcome in patients with heart failure: Coordinating Study Evaluating Outcomes of Advising and Counseling in Heart Failure (COACH) | url = http://archinte.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/168/3/316 | journal = Archives of Internal Medicine | volume = 168 | issue = 3| pages = 316–24 | doi=10.1001/archinternmed.2007.83| pmid = 18268174 }}</ref> * A retrospective cohort study from 2008 found that disease management did not increase the use of drugs recommended for patients after a heart attack.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Chan V, Cooke CE | year = 2008 | title = Pharmacotherapy after myocardial infarction: disease management versus usual care | url = http://www.ajmc.com/media/pdf/AJMC_08jun_Chan352to358.pdf | format = PDF | journal = American Journal of Managed Care | volume = 14 | issue = 6| pages = 352–8 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110721213702/http://www.ajmc.com/media/pdf/AJMC_08jun_Chan352to358.pdf | archivedate = 2011-07-21 | df = | pmid = 18554073 }}</ref> * Of 15 care coordination (disease management) programs followed for two years in a 2008 study, "few programs improved patient behaviors, health, or quality of care" and "no program reduced gross or net expenditures".<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Brown R, etal | year = 2008 | title = 15-site randomized trial of coordinated care in Medicare FFS | url = http://www.cms.hhs.gov/HealthCareFinancingReview/downloads/08Fallpg5.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Health Care Financing Review | volume = 30 | issue = 1| pages = 5–25 | pmid = 19040171 | pmc = 4195047 }}</ref> * After 18 months, a 2008 Florida study found "virtually no overall impacts on hospital or emergency room (ER) use, Medicare expenditures, quality of care, or prescription drug use" for a disease management program.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Esposito D, etal | year = 2008 | title = Impacts of a disease management program for dually eligible beneficiaries | url = http://www.cms.hhs.gov/HealthCareFinancingReview/downloads/08Fallpg27.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Health Care Financing Review | volume = 30 | issue = 1| pages = 27–45 | pmid = 19040172 | pmc = 4195044 }}</ref> * With minor exceptions, a paper published in 2008 did not find significant differences in outcomes among people with asthma randomly assigned to telephonic disease management, augmented disease management (including in-home respiratory therapist visits), or traditional care.<ref name="Galbreath-2008">{{Cite journal | title = Assessing the value of disease management: impact of 2 disease management strategies in an underserved asthma population | journal = Ann Allergy Asthma Immunol | volume = 101 | pages = 599–607 | year = 2008 | doi = 10.1016/S1081-1206(10)60222-0 | pmid = 19119703 |vauthors=Galbreath AD, etal | issue = 6 }}</ref> * A 2009 review by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services of 35 disease management programs that were part of demonstration projects between 1999 and 2008 found that relatively few improved quality in a budget-neutral manner.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1377/hlthaff.28.1.86 | title = Disease management for chronically ill beneficiaries in traditional Medicare | url = http://content.healthaffairs.org/cgi/content/abstract/28/1/86 | journal = Health Aff (Millwood) | volume = 28 | pages = 86–98 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19124858 | issue=1 |vauthors=Bott DM, etal }}</ref> * In a 2009 randomized trial, high- and moderate-intensity disease management did not improve smoking cessation rates after 24 months compared with drug therapy alone.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.7326/0003-4819-150-7-200904070-00003 | title = Impact of Varying Levels of Disease Management on Smoking Cessation: A Randomized Trial | url = http://annals.org/content/150/7/437.full.pdf | journal = Ann Intern Med | volume = 150 | pages = 437–46 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19349629 | issue=7 |vauthors=Ellerbeck EF, etal | pmc = 2825176}}</ref> * A randomized trial published in 2010 determined that disease management reduced a composite score of emergency department visits and hospitalizations among patients discharged from [[Veterans Health Administration|Veterans Administration]] hospitals for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.<ref>{{Cite journal | title = Disease management program for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: a randomized controlled trial | journal = Am J Respir Crit Care Med | volume = 182 | pages = 890–6 | year = 2010 | doi = 10.1164/rccm.200910-1579OC | pmid = 20075385 |vauthors=Rice KL, etal | issue = 7 }}</ref> A 2011 [[post-hoc analysis]] of the study's data estimated that the intervention produced a [[Net (economics)|net]] cost savings of $593 per patient.<ref name="Dewan-2011">{{Cite journal | title = Economic evaluation of a disease management program for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease | journal = COPD | volume = 8 | pages = 153–59 |year = 2011 | doi = 10.3109/15412555.2011.560129 | pmid = 21513435 |vauthors=Dewan NA, etal | issue = 3 }}</ref> * A Spanish study published in 2011 randomized 52 people hospitalized for heart failure to follow-up with usual care, 52 to home visits, 52 to telephone follow-up, and 52 to an in-hospital heart failure unit.<ref name="Gámez-López-2011">{{Cite journal | title = Efectos sobre la mortalidad y reingresos hospitalarios de tres tipos distintos de programas de intervención en pacientes hospitalizados por insuficiencia cardiaca: ensayo clínico aleatorizado (Effects of three different disease management programs on outcomes in patients hospitalized with heart failure: a randomized trial) | journal = Med Clin (Barc) | volume = 138| issue = 5| pages = 192–98|date=May 2011 | doi = 10.1016/j.medcli.2011.03.027 | pmid = 21605879 | url = http://www.elsevier.es/sites/default/files/elsevier/eop/S0025-7753%2811%2900414-3.pdf |vauthors=Gámez-López AL, etal |language=es}}</ref> After a median of 10.8 months of follow-up, there were no significant differences in hospitalization or mortality among the four groups.<ref name="Gámez-López-2011"/> * Among 18- to 64-year-old people with chronic diseases receiving [[Medicaid]], telephone-based disease management in one group of members did not reduce ambulatory care visits, hospitalizations, or expenditures relative to a control group.<ref name="Lin-2011">{{Cite journal |vauthors=Lin WC, Chien HL, Willis G, O'Connell E, Rennie KS, Bottella HM, Ferris TG | title = The Effect of a Telephone-based Health Coaching Disease Management Program on Medicaid members with chronic conditions | journal = Med Care | volume = 50| issue = 1| pages = 91–98| year = 2011 | doi = 10.1097/MLR.0b013e31822dcedf | pmid = 21993059 }}</ref> Furthermore, in this 2011 study, the group receiving disease management had a lower decrease in emergency department visits than the group not receiving disease management.<ref name="Lin-2011"/>
