revision.text:
{{pp-move-indef|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2011}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:Faith (''Buffy the Vampire Slayer'')}} {{Infobox Buffyverse character | Angel = | B&A = Buffy the Vampire Slayer and Angel | name = Faith | series = Buffy the Vampire Slayer | image = Faith Lehane.jpg | caption = Eliza Dushku as Faith | first = "[[Faith, Hope & Trick]]" (1998) | last = "[[Chosen]]" (Buffy, 2003)
"[[Orpheus]]" (Angel, 2003) | creator = [[Joss Whedon]], [[David Greenwalt]] | portrayer = [[Eliza Dushku]] | groups = [[Watchers' Council]]
[[Scooby Gang (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Scooby Gang]]
[[Mayor (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Mayor Wilkins]]
[[Wolfram & Hart]] | role = [[Slayer (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Slayer]] | abilities = [[Superhuman strength|Supernatural strength]], [[speed]], [[endurance|stamina]], [[Sport agility|agility]], and [[reflex]]es
Rapid healing
[[Prophecy|Prophetic dreams]] }} '''Faith''' is a fictional character created by [[Joss Whedon]] for the television series ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]''. Played by actress [[Eliza Dushku]], Faith was introduced in the [[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (season 3)|third season]] of ''Buffy'' and was a focus of that season's overarching plot. She returned for shorter [[story arc]]s on ''Buffy'' and its spinoff ''[[Angel (1999 TV series)|Angel]]''. The character's story is continued in the comic book series ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Eight]]'', and she also appears in [[apocrypha (fiction)|apocryphal]] material in other comic books and novels. Faith was set to receive her own spinoff television series after the final season of ''Buffy'', but Dushku declined the offer and the series was never made. The character later costarred in the 25-issue comic book ''Angel & Faith'' beginning in August 2011; under the banner of ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Nine]]'', the story took place mostly in London and the surrounding area.{{cite web|url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=31615|title=WC11 EXCLUSIVE: Gage is Touched by "Angel & Faith"|work=Comic Book Resources|date=April 1, 2011|accessdate=April 3, 2011}} Seven years after her creation, Whedon gave Faith the surname Lehane for a [[role-playing game]] and subsequent material. The last issue of ''Season Eight'' was the first official canon source to refer to Faith by her full name. Faith is a [[Slayer (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Slayer]]: a girl endowed with supernatural abilities and destined to battle evil creatures like [[Vampire (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|vampires]] and [[Demon (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|demons]]. Created as a [[foil (literature)|foil]] to series [[protagonist]] [[Buffy Summers]], Faith is a slayer from a damaged background who often makes the wrong decision. Events take a toll on Faith's sanity and she slips from being an ally to the main characters into a more villainous role. In later storylines she feels remorse for her past crimes, and with the help of the benevolent vampire [[Angel (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Angel]] she eventually rejoins the side of good, hoping to achieve redemption. ==Appearances== ===Television=== In ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer'''s third season, Faith arrives in [[Sunnydale]],{{cite episode|title=Faith, Hope & Trick|episodelink=Faith, Hope & Trick|series=Buffy the Vampire Slayer|serieslink=Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]], [[David Greenwalt]], [[James A. Contner]]|network=[[The WB Television Network|WB]]|airdate= 1998-10-13|season=3|number=3}} activated as Slayer by the death of [[List of minor Buffy the Vampire Slayer characters#Kendra Young|Kendra]] ([[Bianca Lawson]]) in the episode "[[Becoming (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)#Part 1|Becoming, Part One]]"; Kendra herself had been activated by the temporary death of Buffy ([[Sarah Michelle Gellar]]) in the first season.{{cite episode|title=Becoming, Part One|episodelink=Becoming, Part One|series=Buffy the Vampire Slayer|serieslink=Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]]|network=[[The WB Television Network|WB]]|airdate=1998-05-12|season=2|number=21}} Coming from a [[psychological trauma|traumatic]] and [[child abuse|abusive]] background, Faith tries to fit in with Buffy and her friends, but becomes increasingly isolated and bitter as the season progresses.{{cite episode|title=Revelations|episodelink=Revelations (Buffy episode)|series=Buffy the Vampire Slayer|serieslink=Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]], [[Douglas Petrie]], [[James A. Contner]]|network=[[The WB Television Network|WB]]|airdate= 1998-11-17|season=3|number=7}} A major turning point for the character occurs in the midseason episode "[[Bad Girls (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Bad Girls]]"; while trying to show Buffy the fun side of slaying, Faith accidentally kills [[Minor characters of Buffy the Vampire Slayer#Deputy Mayor Allan Finch|deputy mayor Allan Finch]] ([[Jack Plotnick]]), a human being whom she mistakes for a vampire.{{cite episode|title=Bad Girls|episodelink=Bad Girls (Buffy episode)|series=Buffy the Vampire Slayer|serieslink=Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]], [[Douglas Petrie]], [[Michael Lange]]|network=[[The WB Television Network|WB]]|airdate= 1999-02-09|season=3|number=14}} Feeling more alienated than ever, she betrays the [[Scooby Gang (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Scooby Gang]] and allies herself with the villainous [[Mayor (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|mayor of Sunnydale]] ([[Harry Groener]]),{{cite episode|title=Consequences|episodelink=Consequences (Buffy episode)|series=Buffy the Vampire Slayer|serieslink=Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]], [[Marti Noxon]], [[Michael Gershman (director)]]|network=[[The WB Television Network|WB]]|airdate= 1999-02-16|season=3|number=15}} eventually forming a sincere father-daughter relationship with him. After Faith tries to murder Buffy's vampire lover [[Angel (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Angel]] ([[David Boreanaz]]) under the mayor's orders, the two slayers finally battle it out in the season finale, a confrontation which leaves Faith alive but comatose.{{cite episode|title=Graduation Day, Part One|episodelink=Graduation Day, Part One|series=Buffy the Vampire Slayer|serieslink=Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]]|network=[[The WB Television Network|WB]]|airdate= 1999-05-18|season=3|number=21}} Faith returns to ''Buffy'' for two episodes in the fourth season. Waking up from her coma, she seeks revenge on Buffy by [[body swap|switching their bodies]] using a mystical device called the Draconian Katra left to her by the now-deceased Mayor.{{cite episode|title=This Year's Girl|episodelink=This Year's Girl|series=Buffy the Vampire Slayer|serieslink=Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]], [[Doug Petrie]], [[Michael Gershman (director)]]|network=[[The WB Television Network|WB]]|airdate=2000-02-22|season=4|number=15}} As Buffy is taken into custody by the [[Watchers' Council]] for crimes she did not commit, Faith sees for the first time what it is like to be surrounded by loving friends and family, and Buffy starts to understand Faith, despite being upset with her plight. After feeling obliged to rescue a church full of people from vampires, Faith battles Buffy again, expressing extreme self-hatred before being returned to her own body.{{cite episode|title=Who Are You|episodelink=Who Are You (Buffy episode)|series=Buffy the Vampire Slayer|serieslink=Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]]|network=[[The WB Television Network|WB]]|airdate=2000-02-29|season=4|number=16}} The storyline continues in the first season of spinoff series ''Angel'', as Faith escapes to Los Angeles and is hired by [[Wolfram & Hart]] to assassinate Angel.{{cite episode|title=Five by Five|episodelink=Five by Five (Angel episode)|series=Angel|serieslink=Angel (1999 TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]], [[Jim Kouf]], [[James A. Contner]]|network=[[The WB Television Network|WB]]|airdate=2000-04-25|season=1|number=18}} She plots instead an intricate plan to have Angel kill her, but Angel convinces her to face the consequences of her actions, bonds with her as friend and ally through their similarities, and helps her on the path to redemption. Faith surrenders to the police and is sentenced to a women's prison, where Angel later visits her.{{cite episode|title=Sanctuary|episodelink=Sanctuary (Angel episode)|series=Angel|serieslink=Angel (1999 TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]], [[Tim Minear]], Michael Lange|network=[[The WB Television Network|WB]]|airdate=2000-05-02|season=1|number=19}} Angel, in season four, reverts to the evil Angelus after his soul is removed.{{cite episode|title=Awakening|episodelink=Awakening (Angel episode)|series=Angel|serieslink=Angel (1999 TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]], [[David Fury]], [[Steven S. DeKnight]], [[James A. Contner]]|network=[[The WB Television Network|WB]]|airdate=2003-01-29|season=4|number=10}} Faith is approached by her former [[Watcher (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Watcher]] [[Wesley Wyndam-Pryce]] ([[Alexis Denisof]]), who tells her of Angelus's presence, prompting her prison break to help them.{{cite episode|title=Salvage|episodelink=Salvage (Angel episode)|series=Angel|serieslink=Angel (1999 TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]], [[David Fury]], Jefferson Kibbee|network=[[The WB Television Network|WB]]|airdate=2003-03-05|season=4|number=13}} To help Angel the way he helped her, Faith injects herself with a mystical drug and feeds herself to Angelus to incapacitate him so their allies can work to restore his soul.{{cite episode|title=Release|episodelink=Release (Angel episode)|series=Angel|serieslink=Angel (1999 TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]], Sarah Fain, [[Elizabeth Craft]], [[Steven S. De Knight]]|network=[[The WB Television Network|WB]]|airdate=2003-03-12|season=4|number=14}} She nearly dies from the drug, but during a psychic mind walk Angel persuades her subconscious not to give up, that life is worth living.{{cite episode|title=Orpheus|episodelink=Orpheus (Angel episode)|series=Angel|serieslink=Angel (1999 TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]], [[Mere Smith]], [[Terrence O'Hara]]|network=[[The WB Television Network|WB]]|airdate=2003-03-19|season=4|number=15}} [[File:nofuturecover01.jpg|thumb|left|The character of Faith is expanded upon in media outside of the television series, such as the ''Buffy Season Eight'' comic book.|upright]] A recovered Faith travels back to Sunnydale and plays a significant role in the battle against the [[First Evil]] in the final season of ''Buffy''. She reconciles with Buffy,{{cite episode |title=Dirty Girls|episodelink=Dirty Girls|series=Buffy the Vampire Slayer|serieslink=Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]], [[Drew Goddard]], [[Michael Gershman (director)|Michael Gershman]] |network=[[UPN]]|airdate=2003-04-15|season=7|number=18}} but their relationship is tested when the [[Slayer (Buffyverse)#The Slayer line|potential slayers]] appoint Faith, over Buffy, as their leader.{{cite episode|title=Empty Places|episodelink=Empty Places|series=Buffy the Vampire Slayer|serieslink=Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]], [[Drew Z. Greenberg]], [[James A. Contner]]|network=[[UPN]]|airdate=2003-04-29|season=7|number=19}} This proves disastrous when Faith's plan leads into a trap, with several girls dead. Buffy saves the survivors, and Faith finally makes peace with her.{{cite episode|title=Touched|episodelink=Touched (Buffy episode)|series=Buffy the Vampire Slayer|serieslink=Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]], [[Rebecca Rand Kirshner]], [[David Solomon (producer)|David Solomon]]|network=[[UPN]]|airdate=2003-05-06|season=7|number=20}}{{cite episode|title=End of Days|episodelink=End of Days (Buffy episode)|series=Buffy the Vampire Slayer|serieslink=Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]], [[Jane Espenson]], [[Doug Petrie]], [[Marita Grabiak]]|network=[[UPN]]|airdate=2003-05-13|season=21|number=19}} After a [[one-night stand]] with school principal [[Robin Wood (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Robin Wood]] ([[D.B. Woodside]]), the pair start a romantic relationship when they both survive the battle in the series finale.{{cite episode|title=Chosen|episodelink=Chosen (Buffy episode)|series= Buffy the Vampire Slayer| serieslink=Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|credits=[[Joss Whedon]]|network=[[UPN]]|airdate=2003-05-20|season=7|number=22}} According to Tim Minear, Faith was set to receive [[Undeveloped Buffyverse productions#Faith the Vampire Slayer|her own spinoff]] after ''Buffy'', which would have featured her "on a motorcycle, crossing the Earth, trying to find her place in the world." Dushku, however, chose to pursue other offers in her post-''Buffy'' career.[[Femme Fatales (magazine)|''Femme Fatales'']], May/June 2003. http://spoiledrotten.tvheaven.com/buffy.html.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/cult/news/buffy/2003/04/14/3812.shtml |title=Buffy – Kung Fu Faith (Spoiler) – Buffy news story |publisher=BBC |accessdate=March 20, 2011}}{{cite web|author=Caroline van Oosten de Boer, Milo Vermeulen |url=http://whedonesque.com/comments/1131 |title=Tim Minear and Eliza Duskhu on the aborted Faith spinoff – BtVS |publisher=Whedonesque.com |date=April 14, 2003 |accessdate=March 20, 2011}} ===Literature=== Faith has made appearances in various ''Buffy'' and ''Angel'' [[List of Buffyverse comics|comic books]] and [[List of Buffyverse novels|novels]]. In the ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer'' comic book story "[[Haunted (Buffy comic)|Haunted]]", an imprisoned Faith reveals to Angel her memories of being in a coma between ''Buffy'' seasons three and four. She shared a psychic link with the mayor's spirit and could see him attacking people through his eyes.{{cite book|last=Espenson|first=Jane|authorlink=Jane Espenson |author2=[[Julio Ferreira]] |author3=[[Jeromy Cox]]|title=Buffy the Vampire Slayer: Haunted|publisher=Titan Books Ltd|year=2002|location=London|isbn=978-1-84023-515-9}} "[[Note from the Underground (Buffy comic)|Note from the Underground]]" sees Faith being temporarily released from jail in Angel's custody to help Buffy defeat the Scourge demonic fascists.{{cite book|last=Lobdell|first=Scott|authorlink=Scott Lobdell|title=Buffy the Vampire Slayer: Note from the Underground|publisher=Dark Horse Comics|year=2003|location=[[Milwaukie, Oregon|Milwaukie, OR]]|isbn=978-1-56971-888-9}} ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer: The Faith Trials, Vol. 1'' is a [[novelization]] of ''Buffy'' season three episodes which center around Faith, including "[[Faith, Hope & Trick]]", "[[Bad Girls (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Bad Girls]]", and "[[Consequences (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Consequences]]". These focus specifically on Faith's arrival in Sunnydale and her subsequent turn to the dark side after the death of the deputy mayor.{{cite book|last=Laurence|first=James|authorlink=James Laurence|title=Buffy the Vampire Slayer: The Faith Trials, Vol. 1|publisher=Pocket Books|year=2001|location=New York|isbn=978-0-7434-0044-2}} Faith appeared prominently in her own 2006 novel ''[[Go Ask Malice|Go Ask Malice: A Slayer's Diary]]'' by Robert Joseph Levy, which elaborates on Faith's backstory in [[South Boston, Boston, Massachusetts|South Boston]] and how she came to be Slayer. Written in [[Personal journal|diary]] format, it fleshes out areas of Faith's past hinted at in the show, such as her previous relationships, her alcoholic mother's abuse, and the gruesome killing of her first watcher by the vampire [[Kakistos]].{{cite book|last=Levy|first=Robert Jospeph|authorlink=Robert Joseph Levy|title=Go Ask Malice: A Slayer's Diary|publisher=Pocket Books|year=2006|location=London|isbn=978-1-4165-2635-3}} As Levy says of writing the book, "I wanted to explore the choices she made and the choices that were taken away from her, and how they affected her mental state and her development from potential to Chosen before she arrived."{{cite journal|last=DiLullo|first=Tara|authorlink=Tara DiLullo|date=August 2006|title=A Town Called Malice|journal=[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Magazine incorporating Angel Magazine]]|issue=87|pages=12–13}} (Note: unless otherwise stated, expanded-universe material such as this is not considered [[Buffyverse canon|in canon]] .{{cite news|author=Devin Faraci|url=http://www.chud.com/index.php?type=interviews&id=4434|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070211153424/http://www.chud.com/index.php?type=interviews&id=4434|archivedate=February 11, 2007|title=EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEW: JOSS WHEDON – PART 2|publisher=Chud|date=September 22, 2005|accessdate=November 28, 2007}}{{cite news|author=Ileane Rudolph|url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/Buffy-Vampire-Slayer-35722.aspx|title=''Buffy the Vampire Slayer'' Is Back: The Complete Joss Whedon Q&A|publisher=TV Guide|date=December 7, 2001|accessdate=November 28, 2007}}) Faith appears in the ongoing comic book ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Eight]]'' (2007-11), a canonical continuation of the television series. In the storyline "[[No Future For You]]", Faith goes for Giles on an undercover mission to assassinate rogue slayer Genevieve "Gigi" Savidge,{{Cite comic|writer=[[Brian K. Vaughan]]|penciller=[[Georges Jeanty]]|inker=[[Andy Owen]]|story=[[No Future For You]]|title=[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Eight]]|issue=6|date=September, 2007|publisher=[[Dark Horse Comics]]}} who plans to usurp Buffy's position as leader of the slayers.{{Cite comic|writer=[[Brian K. Vaughan]]|penciller=[[Georges Jeanty]]|inker=[[Andy Owen]]|story=[[No Future For You]]|title=[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Eight]]|issue=7|date=October, 2007|publisher=[[Dark Horse Comics]]}} Faith forms an unexpected connection with Gigi and soon finds herself torn between a new friend and an old enemy.{{Cite comic|writer=[[Brian K. Vaughan]]|penciller=[[Georges Jeanty]]|inker=[[Andy Owen]]|story=[[No Future For You]]|title=[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Eight]]|issue=8|date=November, 2007|publisher=[[Dark Horse Comics]]}} When Gigi discovers her true identity, Faith kills her unintentionally, and she then finds a new purpose with Giles, helping slayers so they won't go down the path she and Gigi did.{{Cite comic|writer=[[Brian K. Vaughan]]|penciller=[[Georges Jeanty]]|inker=[[Andy Owen]]|story=[[No Future For You]]|title=[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Eight]]|issue=9|date=December, 2007|publisher=[[Dark Horse Comics]]}} Faith and Giles later reappear over a year later in "[[Predators and Prey|Safe]]", which recounts one of their missions in Germany.{{Cite comic|writer=[[Jim Krueger]]|penciller=[[Cliff Richards]]|inker=[[Andy Owen]]|story=[[Predators and Prey|Predators and Prey, Part IV (Safe)]]|title=[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Eight]]|issue=24|date=April, 2009|publisher=[[Dark Horse Comics]]}} When she reconnects with Buffy to face the threats of the villain Twilight in "[[Retreat (Buffy comic)|Retreat]]",{{Cite comic|writer=[[Jane Espenson]]|penciller=[[Georges Jeanty]]|inker=[[Andy Owen]]|story=[[Retreat (Buffy comic)|Retreat, Part I]]|title=[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Eight]]|issue=26|date=July, 2009|publisher=[[Dark Horse Comics]]}} he captures her, Giles and Andrew;{{Cite comic|writer=[[Joss Whedon]]|penciller=[[Georges Jeanty]]|inker=[[Andy Owen]]|story=Turbulence|title=[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Eight]]|issue=26|date=January, 2010|publisher=[[Dark Horse Comics]]}} she then witnesses the reveal of Twilight's identity as Angel, in "Twilight, Part II".{{Cite comic|writer=[[Brad Meltzer]]|penciller=[[Cliff Richards]]|inker=[[Andy Owen]]|story=[[Twilight (Buffy comic)|Twilight, Part II]]|title=[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Eight]]|issue=33|date=March, 2009|publisher=[[Dark Horse Comics]]}} In the final story arc "[[Last Gleaming]]", Faith battles in the ruins of Sunnydale alongside other Scooby Gang members and slayers. Meanwhile, Angel -- possessed by the Twilight entity -- snaps Giles' neck, to stop the destruction of its power source; a grief-stricken Buffy destroys it, freeing Angel from Twilight's possession, but cutting off almost all magic from the universe.{{Cite comic|writer=[[Scott Allie]], Joss Whedon|penciller=Georges Jeanty|inker=[[Andy Owen]]|story=[[Last Gleaming]]|title=[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Eight]]|issue=39|date=December, 2010|publisher=[[Dark Horse Comics]]}} In the final issue set some time later, Giles' [[will (law)|will]] is read, leaving all his worldly assets, except one book, to Faith. In Faith's care is a distraught Angel, whom she intends to rehabilitate.{{Cite comic|writer=Joss Whedon|penciller=Georges Jeanty|inker=[[Andy Owen]]|story=[[Last Gleaming]]|title=[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Eight]]|issue=40|date=January, 2011|publisher=[[Dark Horse Comics]]}} Following ''Season Eight'', Faith received her own title in ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Nine|Angel & Faith]]'' (2011-2013), a companion series to ''Season Nine''. The story depicts Angel and Faith residing in Giles' London home, attending to his unfinished business and fighting the forces of evil in the city, while Angel pursues a covert plan to resurrect Giles. Faith mentors a group of slayers, but those relationships are strained by her friendship with Angel. Ultimately, the group averts the apocalypse, and resurrects Giles, as a young boy. The story ends with Faith taking some time alone to find herself. She is next seen in ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season Ten]]'' (2014-2016) when she brings Giles to reconnect with Buffy, and is hurt when Giles tells her that Buffy is his first priority. In the second volume of ''Angel & Faith'', Faith finds a home in [[Kennedy (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Kennedy]]'s [[private security]] slayer firm, and is troubled by a mission to rescue [[Riley Finn]], whom she slept with while posing as Buffy years ago. She eventually returns to London to fight alongside Angel against the ancient demon Archaeus, who had been terrorizing the city. ==Concept and creation== {{Quote_box|width=30%|align=right|quote="I know Faith's not going to be on the cover of ''Sanity Fair'', but... she had it rough. Different circumstances, that could be me."|source=—Buffy empathizes with Faith in "[[Doppelgangland]]", echoing the intended parallels between the two Slayers.}}The initial concept for Faith's character was "the road not taken", a Slayer who makes the wrong choices in life.{{cite video|people=[[Joss Whedon]], [[Jane Espenson]], [[Marti Noxon]], [[Eliza Dushku]]|title="Season 3 Overview" (''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]'' [[Buffy the Vampire Slayer DVDs#Season 3|The Complete Third Season]] DVD Special Features)|medium=DVD (Region 2)|location=United States|publisher=20th Century Fox|date=2001}} She is intended to be a reflection of what Buffy could have become were it not for her support system of friends and family. The question the writers wanted to answer was, how would upbringing and environment affect the type of people they would become later in life? Whedon describes her as everything Buffy would never let herself become; although Buffy is tempted by Faith's approach to slaying, she ultimately decides not to make the same choices herself. Some fans argue that the show developed a lesbian [[subtext]] for Faith and Buffy; writer [[Jane Espenson]] says Whedon didn't intend this, but admitted it was there after he had it pointed out to him, jokingly attributing this to his subconscious.{{cite web|url=http://www.afterelton.com/blog/michaeljensen/live-chat-with-jane-espenson|title=Live Chat with Jane Espenson|last=Jensen|first=Michael|work=AfterElton.com|date=March 19, 2009|accessdate=August 15, 2009}} With Faith, the writers explored the nature of power and the boundaries and consequences of its use. They wanted to address the issue that regardless of whether the creatures a Slayer kills are good or evil, she is still a professional killer. Co-executive producer [[Doug Petrie]], writer of Faith-centric episodes such as "[[Revelations (Buffy episode)|Revelations]]" and "[[Bad Girls (Buffy episode)|Bad Girls]]", says one thing he loves about the character is that Faith is not wrong to describe herself and Buffy as killers. He notes that Faith believes her contributions to society relieve her of any legal or moral responsibilities, a view which Buffy does not share. When writing Faith, Petrie looked to [[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller]]'s violent [[Marvel Comics]] character [[Elektra (comics)|Elektra Natchios]] for inspiration, claiming that "in a different, teen, punkier context, Faith is so much like Elektra."{{cite book|last=Golden|first=Christopher|authorlink=Christopher Golden |author2=[[Stephen R. Bissette]] |author3=[[Thomas E. Sniegoski]]|title=Buffy the Vampire Slayer: The Monster Book|publisher=Pocket Books|year=2000|location=New York|pages=VI|isbn=978-0-671-04259-2}} After the series ended, Faith got a surname in 2005. When Whedon was asked by Eden Studios to create Faith and Kendra surnames for a [[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (roleplaying game)|''Buffy the Vampire Slayer'' role-playing game]], he chose Lehane for Faith because he wanted something [[South Boston|Southie]].[[Joss Whedon]] announced in January 2005 that Faith's surname was "Lehane," and this would be used in all future products, starting with Eden Studios' [[Buffyverse role-playing games|''Buffy the Vampire Slayer'' role-playing game]] . The name appears in Eden's books and is considered to be [[canon (fiction)|canonical]]. Whedon explained at the time: : ''There was this role playing game or something. They said she hadda have a last name for her so I chose Lehane 'cause I wanted something [[South Boston|Southie]], just as you thought.'' — [http://whedonesque.com/?comments=5682#47049 Joss Whedon at whedonesque.com] ==Characterization== Actress Dushku describes Faith as the working class Slayer, a reason she feels so many people identify with her. She was written as a sympathetic character. Petrie claims "I connected with Faith early on. I love that character. She's totally tragic." According to him, "the whole key to Faith is that she's in pain. If you took that away, she would be a monster. But she's so lonely and so desperate, and all of her toughness comes out of trying to cover that. That's what real monsters are made of. No one thinks they're really a monster." Petrie says Faith's main motivation is to find a family and friends; she sees treacherous watcher Gwendolyn Post as the mother she never had, the Scooby Gang as the friends she never had, and the mayor as the father she never had. "She's always looking for a family and always coming up short and making these horrible choices, and it drove her insane," he says. "Plus I think she was missing a couple of screws to begin with. 'If you don't love me, you will fear me,' is kind of her [[modus operandi|m.o]]. She's not a stable girl, but a fun one." Petrie describes the character's name as "wildly ironic" due to her cynical nature. "She's the most faithless character we've got. She doesn't trust herself or anyone around her. We try to do that a lot with our monsters. It's much more fun if you look at it from their point of view."{{cite book|last=Golden|first=Christopher|authorlink=Christopher Golden |author2=[[Stephen R. Bissette]] |author3=[[Thomas E. Sniegoski]]|title=Buffy the Vampire Slayer: The Monster Book|publisher=Pocket Books|year=2000|location=New York|pages=368–369|isbn=978-0-671-04259-2}} Writer Espenson thinks one reason why Faith elicits sympathy is the touching father/daughter relationship between her and the mayor, and compares their affection with that between vampires [[Spike (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Spike]] and [[Drusilla (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Drusilla]] in the earlier season. The writers wanted to make both Faith and the mayor as human as possible by showing their need for connection and love as passionate as the heroic characters. Dushku asserts that Faith's bond with the Mayor is due to his being one of the few people in her life who doesn't put her down, which is something she battled with her whole life. Dushku goes on to say Faith's misplaced trust in the Mayor "leads her into being more crazy". In the ''Angel'' season one episode "[[Sanctuary (Angel episode)|Sanctuary]]", Faith bonds with vampire-with-a-soul Angel; executive producer David Greenwalt explains Angel can help because he's able to understand her suffering and to help her atone for her sins.{{cite video|people=[[David Greenwalt]]|title="Featurette: Season 1" (''[[Angel (1999 TV series)|Angel]]'' [[Angel DVDs#Season 1|The Complete First Season]] DVD Special Features)|medium=DVD (Region 2)|location=United States|publisher=20th Century Fox|date=2001}} Faith returns the favor in ''Angel'''s fourth season, when she's the only one determined to defeat his soulless alter ego Angelus without killing Angel in the process. Actor Boreanaz explains, "I think having a character like Faith come back at a pivotal point when she finds out Angelus is loose is really, for her character, a way of saying: 'I'm paying you back, Angel, for saving me, therefore, I'm gonna save you.'" The writers found it an interesting dynamic to have former bad girl Faith play an heroic role against the villainous protagonist Angel.{{cite video|people=[[David Boreanaz]], [[David Fury]]|title="Prophecies: Season 4 Overview" (''[[Angel (1999 TV series)|Angel]]'' [[Angel DVDs#Season 4|The Complete Fourth Season]] DVD Special Features)|medium=DVD (Region 2)|location=United States|publisher=20th Century Fox|date=2004}} {{Quote_box|width=30%|align=left|quote="Much as I love Buffy, I'm way happier writing flawed, damaged people who don't always make the right decisions. Faith is such a complex, beautiful character."|source=—[[Brian K. Vaughan]] explains what attracted him to the character.{{cite news|author=Matt Brady|url=http://forum.newsarama.com/showthread.php?t=126514|title=TALKING FAITH & BUFFY WITH BRIAN K VAUGHAN|publisher=Newsarama|date=August 23, 2007|accessdate=November 27, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100107064400/http://forum.newsarama.com/showthread.php?t=126514|archivedate=January 7, 2010|df=mdy-all}}}} Faith came back for the final season of ''Buffy'' because, according to David Solomon, "she had been such a crucial character at a very specific junction in the series that there would be no way to tie it up without her." Yet the season seven dynamic between the two Slayers has changed. As Rebecca Rand Kirshner explains, Faith is "no longer such a complete opposite of Buffy. And there's sort of a subtler and more complicated dynamic between them". As Buffy fights her unwanted role as mentor to the Potential Slayers, the writers used Faith to create an outside conflict about Buffy's leadership abilities. Although she questions Buffy and the choices she makes, Faith is no longer her enemy. In the episode "[[Empty Places]]", when the Potentials lose trust in Buffy and appoint Faith as their leader, the decision literally blows up in their faces. As Drew Goddard explains, "Faith is like the cool aunt that everyone loves, because the cool aunt doesn't have the responsibility of raising the children. She just gets to show up and have fun. The problem is, Faith is not ready to lead. She's damaged in her own way. She's just beginning to pull herself together. As much as she wants to be Buffy, she has to learn how to become Faith."{{cite video|people=[[Joss Whedon]], [[Drew Goddard]], [[David Solomon (producer)|David Solomon]], [[Rebecca Rand Kirshner]]|title="Season 7 Overview – Buffy: Full Circle" (''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]'' [[Buffy the Vampire Slayer DVDs#Season 7|The Complete Seventh Season]] DVD Special Features)|medium=DVD (Region 2)|location=United States|publisher=20th Century Fox|date=2004}} When writing ''Go Ask Malice'', author Levy encountered a number of issues when writing a backstory for Faith; one was retaining the character's mystery. Levy felt many aspects of Faith's background, such as her delinquency and promiscuity, could be intuited by the show's viewers, and he didn't want to spell everything out in some kind of case study. To do something nontraditional, Levy told the story in a diary format, watching many episodes of the series to get a feel for the cadence of her voice. He looked to Faith's own personality to overcome his fear of writing such a popular character. "She's not hesitant and in a lot of ways, I took a lot of inspiration from the character itself in terms of creative process — to really go for it and be strong in my choices". ==See also== {{Portal|United States|Television|Fictional characters}} *[[Women warriors in literature and culture]] {{Clear}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{wikiquote|Buffy the Vampire Slayer}} {{Clear}} {{Buffy the Vampire Slayer}} {{Angel (1999 TV series)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Faith (Buffy The Vampire Slayer)}} [[Category:Angel (TV series) characters]] [[Category:Buffy the Vampire Slayer characters]] [[Category:Female characters in television]] [[Category:Fictional assassins]] [[Category:Fictional characters from Boston]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1998]] [[Category:Fictional characters with accelerated healing]] [[Category:Fictional characters with precognition]] [[Category:Fictional characters with superhuman strength]] [[Category:Fictional characters who can move at superhuman speeds]] [[Category:Fictional henchmen]] [[Category:Fictional prison escapees]] [[Category:Slayers (Buffyverse)]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:New Zealand law]]; added [[Category:Health law in New Zealand]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=December 2012}} The '''Health Practitioners Disciplinary Tribunal''' of [[New Zealand]] hears and determines disciplinary proceedings brought against health practitioners.
The Tribunal was created by section 84 Health Practitioners Competence Assurance Act 2003<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/2003/0048/latest/whole.html |title=Health Practitioners Competence Assurance Act 2003 No 48 (as at 01 August 2011), Public Act – New Zealand Legislation |work=legislation.govt.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=18 November 2011}}</ref> and established 18 September 2004. It supersedes the [[Medical Practitioners Disciplinary Tribunal]] of New Zealand.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.mpdt.org.nz/ |title=Medical Practitioners Disciplinary Tribunal |work=mpdt.org.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=18 November 2011}}</ref>
The Tribunal is administered by the [[Ministry of Health (New Zealand)|Ministry of Health]] and covers a range of professions including medical professions ([[medical practitioners]], [[nurses]] and [[midwives]]), dental professions ([[dentists]], [[dental therapists]], [[dental hygienists]]), [[pharmacists]], [[osteopaths]], and [[chiropractors]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.hpdt.org.nz/ |title=Health Practitioners Disciplinary Tribunal|work=hpdt.org.nz |year=2011 |accessdate=18 November 2011}}</ref>
==Notable people associated with the Tribunal== *[[Keith Paroa Curry]]{{mdash}}de-registered for grooming young girls.
==External links== * [http://www.hpdt.org.nz Official Site]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Medical and health organisations based in New Zealand]] [[Category:Health law in New Zealand]] [[Category:Medical law]]
{{NewZealand-law-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Branch structure */
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox Union|<!-- Include all unused fields for future use. See [[template talk:Infobox Union]] for usage. --> |name= Health Services Union |members=70,000 (2015) |country= [[Australia]] |affiliation= [[Australian Council of Trade Unions|ACTU]] |founded= 1911 (as Hospital and Asylum Attendants and Employees Union Australia) |office= [[Melbourne]] |key people=Lloyd Williams (National President), Chris Brown (National Secretary) |website= {{URL|www.hsu.net.au}} }} The '''Health Services Union''' (HSU) is a specialist health [[trade union|union]] with around 70,000 members working in the healthcare and social assistance industries across [[Australia]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://hsu.net.au/about-us/|title=About Us|publisher=[[HSU National]]|accessdate=16 November 2015|date=16 November 2015}}</ref>
The membership of the union includes [[physician|doctors]], and allied health professionals such as [[physiotherapy|physiotherapists]] and [[radiography|radiographers]], [[ambulance]] officers, clerical and administrative staff, managers and support staff.
The HSU National Office is located in [[Melbourne, Victoria]]. Its current National Secretary is Chris Brown.
==Branch structure== The HSU is a federated union, with branches in every state and territory of Australia. Each branch of the HSU covers different workers depending on the state they reside, their workplace and their occupation. Below is a list of the nine branches of the HSU. * HSU NSW/ACT * HSU QLD * HSU SA/NT * HSU TAS (trading as the Health and Community Services Union - HACSU) * HSU VIC No. 1 (trading as the Health Workers Union - HWU) * HSU VIC No. 2 (trading as the Health and Community Services Union - HACSU) * HSU VIC No. 3 (trading as the [[Victorian Allied Health Professionals Association]] - VAHPA) * HSU VIC No. 4 (trading as the Medical Scientists Association of Victoria; Victorian Psychologists Association and; Association of Hospital Pharmacists) * HSU WA
==History== The union officially came into existence in 1991 with the amalgamation of two existing unions, the Hospital Employees' Federation (HEF) and The Health and Research Employees Association (HREA).<ref>{{cite web|title=The HSU: anatomy of a Labor nightmare|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-05-03/the-hsu-anatomy-of-a-labor-nightmare/3986558|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=4 May 2012}}</ref> But its origins date back to the early years of the twentieth century when organisations of [[hospital]] employees were first formed in [[Australia]].
Over the years the membership of the unions that eventually came together to form the HSU has been based around a nucleus of hospital staff and [[psychiatric]] care staff. But it has gone much further to include ambulance, [[aged care]], [[community health]], [[disability]] sector, hospital [[scientists]], [[mind|mental]] health and [[drug abuse|drug]] and [[alcohol]] workers.
=== Financial controversy === {{main|Health Services Union expenses affair}} A former HSU national Secretary, [[Craig Thomson (politician)|Craig Thomson]], faced allegations from 2008<ref name="Thomson suspended">[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-04-29/craig-thomson-leaves-labor-party/3978614 "Embattled Thomson suspended from Labor Party"]. ''ABC News'' [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]], 29 April 2012. Retrieved 7 May 2012 (updated)</ref> that he used an HSU union credit card to pay for [[Call girl|escorts]] and other financial improprieties with the card. Amid the allegations, the [[Australian Council of Trade Unions]] (ACTU) suspended the HSU's membership.<ref name="ACTU suspends HSU">{{cite news|title=ACTU suspends Health Services Union|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-04-05/actu-suspends-health-services-union/3935476|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=7 May 2012|newspaper=ABC News|date=5 May 2012}}</ref> Thomson maintains his innocence, but in May 2012, a report by [[Fair Work Australia]] recommended that [[civil court]] action be taken against Thomson for what the report says was a "substantial misuse of members' funds".<ref name="Fair work report">{{cite news|last=Wright|first=Jessica|title=Fair Work moves on Thomson over 'misuse' of HSU funds and escort services|url=http://www.smh.com.au/opinion/political-news/fair-work--moves-on-thomson-over-misuse-of-hsu-funds-and-escort-services-20120507-1y86c.html|accessdate=7 May 2012|newspaper=Sydney Morning Herald|date=7 May 2012}}</ref> On 31 January 2013, Thomson was arrested and was expected to face 150 fraud charges in Wyong Local Court.<ref>{{cite news|title=Craig Thomson arrested by fraud squad|url=http://www.smh.com.au/opinion/political-news/craig-thomson-arrested-by-fraud-squad-20130131-2dmnn.html|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=31 January 2013|accessdate=|author=}}</ref>
Following regulatory and administrative investigations, criminal trials and a subsequent [[appeal]], on 15 December 2014, Thomson, a former [[Australian Labor Party|Labor]] politician, was found [[guilt (law)|guilty]] in the [[County Court of Victoria|Victorian County Court]] of thirteen charges of [[theft]] and convicted and fined A$25,000.<ref name="Age-2014-12-17">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/craig-thomson-convicted-and-fined-25000-20141217-1294ha.html|title=Craig Thomson convicted and fined $25,000|work=[[The Age]]|date=17 December 2014|accessdate=17 December 2014|author=Cooper, Adam}}</ref><ref name="ABC-2014-12-17">{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-12-17/craig-thomson-fined-escapes-jail-time-over-hsu-theft/5972518|title=Craig Thomson appeal: Former federal MP escapes prison term over theft from Health Services Union|work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|location=Australia|date=17 December 2014|accessdate=17 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="ABC-2014-12-15"/> Forty-nine charges of obtaining financial advantage by deception were dismissed<ref name="ABC-2014-12-15">{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-12-15/craig-thomson-appeal-former-mp-not-guilty-on-49-charges/5967124|title=Craig Thomson appeal: Former MP not guilty of 49 fraud charges, guilty of theft|author=Carlyon, Peta|date=15 December 2014|accessdate=15 December 2014|work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|location=Australia}}</ref> following an earlier finding in the [[Melbourne Magistrates Court]] on 18 February 2014 against Thomson of [[fraud|defrauding]] the HSU in order to pay for personal expenses.<ref name="Austguilty">{{cite news|last=Akerman|first=Pia|title=Craig Thomson found guilty of defrauding HSU |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/craig-thomson-found-guilty-of-defrauding-hsu/story-e6frg6nf-1226830337709 |accessdate=18 February 2014 |newspaper=[[The Australian]]}}</ref><ref name="SMHguilty">{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/comment/how-craig-thomson-came-undone-20140218-32xzv.html |title=How Craig Thomson came undone |author=Davies, Anne |date=18 February 2014 |newspaper=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] |accessdate=18 February 2014 }}</ref><ref name="SMHguilty1">{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/craig-thomson-found-guilty-of-fraud-theft-charges-20140218-32xay.html?rand=1392700646386 |title=Craig Thomson found guilty of fraud, theft charges |author=Cooper, Adam |date=18 February 2014 |newspaper=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] |accessdate=18 February 2014 |agency=[[Australian Associated Press|AAP]] }}</ref><ref name="ABCpmguilty">{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2013/s3947384.htm |author=Donovan, Samantha |title=Thomson found guilty on fraud/theft charges |date=18 February 2014 |work=[[PM (ABC Radio)|PM]] |publisher=[[ABC Radio and Regional Content|ABC Radio]] |accessdate=18 February 2014 }}</ref> On 25 March 2014, Thomson was convicted on 65 charges of fraud and theft for using Health Services Union funds for personal benefit and [[sentence (law)|sentenced]] to twelve months [[imprisonment]], with nine months [[suspended sentence#Australia|suspended]] over two years. Thomson's legal team immediately lodged an appeal against the conviction and sentence and was granted [[Bail#By a court|bail]].<ref name="ABC-2014-03-25">{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-03-25/craig-thomson-fraud-hsu-sentencing/5342428 |title=Craig Thomson: Former Labor MP sentenced for defrauding Health Services Union |date=25 March 2014 |work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |location=Australia |accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref><ref name="HS-2014-03-25">{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/law-order/former-mp-craig-thomson-sentenced-to-three-months-jail/story-fni0fee2-1226863919858 |title=Former MP Craig Thomson sentenced to three months’ jail |date=25 March 2014 |work=[[The Herald Sun]] |accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref><ref name="SMH-2014-03-25">{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/craig-thomson-sentenced-to-12-months-jail-nine-months-suspended-20140325-35f67.html#ixzz2xS9PgXJQ |title=Craig Thomson sentenced to 12 months' jail, nine months suspended |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |author=Cooper, Adam |date=25 March 2014 |accessdate=25 March 2014 }}</ref><ref name="Aust-2014-03-25">{{cite news |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/policy/craig-thomson-bailed-ahead-of-appeal-over-jail-sentence-for-hsu-fraud/story-fn59noo3-1226863996174 |title=Craig Thomson bailed ahead of appeal over jail sentence for HSU fraud |work=[[The Australian]] |author=Akerman, Pia |agency=[[Australian Associated Press|AAP]] |date=25 March 2014 |accessdate=25 March 2014 }}</ref><ref name="Yahoo-2014-12-15">{{cite web|title=Prosecution error clears Thomson|url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/a/25770688/ex-mp-craig-thomson-to-learn-his-fate/|website=au.news.yahoo.com|accessdate=15 December 2014|date=15 December 2014}}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== {{Portal|Organized labour}} *[http://www.hsu.net.au Official website] *[http://www.hsu.asn.au Official website - NSW Branch] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050625080457/http://www.actu.asn.au/ Australian Council of Trade Unions] * {{cite web|url= http://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Senate_Committees?urleet_ctte/ctte_info/Final_Report_HSU_National_Office_investigation.pdf |title=Fair Work Australia Report into the National Branch of the Health Services Union received by the Committee 7 May 2012 }} {{small|(7396KB)}}

revision.comment: /* See also */
revision.text:
'''Health human resources''' ('''HHR''') – also known as '''human resources for health''' ('''HRH''') or '''health workforce''' – is defined as "all people engaged in actions whose primary intent is to enhance health", according to the [[World Health Organization]]'s [[World Health Report|''World Health Report 2006'']].World Health Organization. ''The world health report 2006: working together for health'', Geneva, 2006 – http://www.who.int/whr/2006 Human resources for health are identified as one of the core building blocks of a [[health system]].World Health Organization. [http://www.who.int/healthsystems/topics/en/index.html Health Systems Topics.] Geneva. They include [[physicians]], [[nurses|nursing professionals]], [[midwives]], [[dentists]], [[allied health professions]], [[community health worker]]s, social health workers and other [[health care provider]]s, as well as health management and support personnel – those who may not deliver services directly but are essential to effective health system functioning, including [[health administration|health services managers]], [[health information management|medical records and health information technicians]], health economists, health supply chain managers, medical secretaries and others. The field of health human resources deals with issues such as [[workforce planning|planning]], development, performance, [[human resource management|management]], [[employee retention|retention]], information, and research on [[human resources]] for the [[health care]] sector. In recent years, raising awareness of the critical role of HRH in strengthening health system performance and improving population health outcomes has placed the health workforce high on the [[global health]] agenda.Grepin K, Savedoff WD. "10 Best Resources on ... health workers in developing countries." ''Health Policy and Planning'', 2009; 24(6):479–482 http://heapol.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/full/24/6/479 == Global situation == [[Image:SOWM2010 critical shortage.svg|thumb|Nations identified with critical shortages of health care workers]] The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates a shortage of almost 4.3 million physicians, midwives, nurses and support workers worldwide. The shortage is most severe in 57 of the poorest countries, especially in sub-Saharan Africa. The situation was declared on [[World Health Day|World Health Day 2006]] as a "health workforce crisis" – the result of decades of underinvestment in health worker education, training, [[wage]]s, working environment and management. Shortages of skilled for health workers are also reported in many specific care areas. For example, there is an estimated shortage of 1.18 million [[mental health professional]]s, including 55,000 psychiatrists, 628,000 nurses in mental health settings, and 493,000 psychosocial care providers needed to treat mental disorders in 144 low- and middle-income countries.Scheffler RM et al. ''Human resources for mental health: workforce shortages in low- and middle-income countries''. Geneva, World Health Organization, 2011 – available on http://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2011/9789241501019_eng.pdf Shortages of [[birth attendant|skilled birth attendants]] in many developing countries remains an important barrier to improving [[maternal health]] outcomes. Many countries, both developed and developing, report maldistribution of skilled health workers leading to [[Health care provider#Shortages of health professionals|shortages in rural and underserved areas]]. Regular statistical updates on the global health workforce situation are collated in the WHO ''Global Health Observatory''.World Health Organization. [http://www.who.int/gho/health_workforce/en/ ''Global Health Observatory (GHO) data: Health workforce.''] Geneva. Accessed 8 Aug 2017. However, the evidence base remains fragmented and incomplete, largely related to weaknesses in the underlying [[HRHIS|human resource information systems]] (HRIS) within countries.Dal Poz MR et al. (eds). ''Handbook on monitoring and evaluation of human resources for health'', Geneva, World Health Organization, 2009 – available on http://www.who.int/hrh/resources/handbook/en/index.html In order to learn from best practices in addressing health workforce challenges and strengthening the evidence base, an increasing number of HHR practitioners from around the world are focusing on issues such as HHR advocacy, surveillance and collaborative practice. Some examples of global HRH partnerships include: * [http://my.ibpinitiative.org/HIRG Health Workforce Information Reference Group (HIRG)] * [http://www.who.int/hrh/network/en/ Global Health Workforce Network] == Research == Health workforce research is the investigation of how social, economic, organizational, political and policy factors affect access to health care professionals, and how the organization and composition of the workforce itself can affect health care delivery, quality, [[health equity|equity]], and costs. Many government [[health department]]s, academic institutions and related agencies have established research programs to identify and quantify the scope and nature of HHR problems leading to [[health policy]] in building an innovative and sustainable health services workforce in their jurisdiction. Some examples of HRH information and research dissemination programs include: * [http://www.human-resources-health.com ''Human Resources for Health''] journal * [http://www.med.unsw.edu.au/HRHweb.nsf HRH Knowledge Hub, University of New South Wales, Australia] * [http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20011112014316/http://chws.albany.edu/ Center for Health Workforce Studies, University of Albany, New York] * [http://www.cihi.ca/CIHI-ext-portal/internet/EN/Theme/spending+and+health+workforce/cihi010658 Canadian Institute for Health Information: ''Spending and Health Workforce''] * [http://hrhindia.org/ Public Health Foundation of India: ''Human Resources for Health in India''] * [http://www.hrhobservatory.sd National Human Resources for Health Observatory of Sudan] * [http://www.oecd.org/document/54/0,2340,en_2649_37407_1935094_1_1_1_37407,00.html OECD Human Resources for Health Care Study] == Policy and planning == In some countries and jurisdictions, health workforce planning is distributed among [[Labour economics|labour market]] participants. In others, there is an explicit [[health policy|policy or strategy]] adopted by governments and systems to plan for adequate numbers, distribution and quality of health workers to meet health care goals. For one, the [[International Council of Nurses]] reports:International Council of Nurses. ''Health human resources planning''. Geneva, 2008 – {{cite web |url=http://www.ichrn.com/publications/factsheets/Health-Human-Resources-Plan_EN.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-04-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322161502/http://www.ichrn.com/publications/factsheets/Health-Human-Resources-Plan_EN.pdf |archivedate=2012-03-22 |df= }}
The objective of HHRP [health human resources planning] is to provide the right number of health care workers with the right knowledge, skills, attitudes, and qualifications, performing the right tasks in the right place at the right time to achieve the right predetermined health targets.
An essential component of planned HRH targets is [[supply and demand]] modeling, or the use of appropriate data to link population health needs and/or health care delivery targets with human resources supply, distribution and [[workforce productivity|productivity]]. The results are intended to be used to generate evidence-based policies to guide workforce sustainability.Dal Poz MR et al. ''Models and tools for health workforce planning and projections.'' Geneva, World Health Organization, 2010 – http://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2010/9789241599016_eng.pdfHealth Canada. [http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/hcs-sss/hhr-rhs/strateg/index-eng.php ''Health Human Resource Strategy (HHRS)''.] Accessed 12 April 2011. In resource-limited countries, HRH planning approaches are often driven by the needs of targeted programmes or projects, for example, those responding to the [[Millennium Development Goals]] or, more recently, the [[Sustainable Development Goals]].Dreesch N et al. "An approach to estimating human resource requirements to achieve the Millennium Development Goals." ''Health Policy and Planning'', 2005; 20(5):267–276. The WHO ''Workload Indicators of Staffing Need'' (WISN) is an HRH planning and management tool that can be adapted to local circumstances.World Health Organization. ''Workload Indicators of Staffing Need (WISN): User's manual.'' Geneva, 2010 – http://www.who.int/hrh/resources/wisn_user_manual/en/ It provides health managers a systematic way to make staffing decisions in order to better manage their human resources, based on a health worker's [[workload]], with activity (time) standards applied for each workload component at a given health facility. ===Global Code of Practice on the International Recruitment of Health Personnel=== The main international policy framework for addressing shortages and maldistribution of health professionals is the ''Global Code of Practice on the International Recruitment of Health Personnel'', adopted by the WHO's 63rd [[World Health Assembly]] in 2010.''International recruitment of health personnel: global code of practice.'' Resolution adopted by the Sixty-third World Health Assembly, Geneva, May 2010 – available on http://apps.who.int/gb/e/e_wha63.html The Code was developed in a context of increasing debate on international health worker recruitment, especially in some higher income countries, and its impact on the ability of many developing countries to deliver [[primary health care]] services. Although non-binding on the Member States and recruitment agencies, the Code promotes principles and practices for the ethical international recruitment of health personnel. It also advocates the strengthening of health personnel information systems to support effective health workforce policies and planning in countries. == See also == *[[Canada's Health Care providers, 2007|''Canada's Health Care Providers, 2007'']], published by the Canadian Institute for Health Information *[[Health care providers]] *[[Health systems]] *[[HRHIS|Human resources for health information system]]s *''[[Human Resources for Health]]'', open access journal *[[Interprofessional education|Interprofessional education and collaborative practice]] in health care *[[NHS National Workforce Projects]], part of the English National Health Service *[[Physician supply|Physician shortage]] / [[Nursing shortage]] == References == == External links == *[http://www.who.int/hrh/en/ World Health Organization] programme of work on health human resources *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051110124648/http://secure.cihi.ca/cihiweb/dispPage.jsp?cw_page=hhrdata_e Human Resources for Health Databases], [[Canadian Institute for Health Information]] *[http://www.eldis.org/go/topics/dossiers/human-resources-for-health Human resources for health in developing countries] – a dossier from the Institute for Development Studies *[http://www.who.int/hrh/tools/en/index.html Compendium of tools and guidelines] for HRH situation analysis, planning, policies and management systems *[http://my.ibpinitiative.org/HIRG Online community of practice for HRH practitioners] on strengthening health workforce information systems *[http://www.hrhresourcecenter.org/ Human Resources for Health Global Resource Center] online collection of HRH research and materials, supported by the IntraHealth International-led CapacityPlus project *[http://www.capacityproject.org/hris/hris-toolkit/index.html HRIS strengthening implementation toolkit] *[http://www.hrh-observatory.afro.who.int/ Africa Health Workforce Observatory] [[Category:Human resource management]] [[Category:Healthcare occupations]] [[Category:Global health]]

revision.comment: /* Poisoning */
revision.text:
'''Infant and toddler safety''' are those actions and modifications put into place to keep babies and toddlers safe from accidental injury and death. Many accidents, injuries and deaths are preventable.<ref name = aapfurn>{{cite web | publisher = American Academy of Pediatrics | first = Lois| last = Lee| url = https://www.aap.org/en-us/aap-voices/Pages/How-a-Hole-in-the-Wall-Can-Save-a-Childs-Life.aspx | title = How a Hole in the Wall Can Save a Child's Life | date = 6 July 2017| accessdate = 27 July 2017}}</ref>
Infants begin to crawl around six to nine months of age. When they crawl, they are exposed to many dangers. Anticipating the development of the baby and toddler aids caregivers in identifying hazards before they are discovered by the child.<ref name=NIH2017>{{cite web|title=Making Your Home Safe For Baby|url=https://www.womenshealth.gov/pregnancy/getting-ready-baby/making-your-home-safe-baby|publisher = Office on Women’s Health, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services|accessdate=17 July 2017|date=1 February 2017}}{{PD-notice}}</ref>
==General recommendations== US government agencies recommend that caregivers take the following precautions:
* Covering all unused electrical sockets with outlet plugs. * Keeping cords out of baby's reach. Tack up cords to vertical blinds and move furniture, lamps, or electronics to hide cords. * Securing furniture and electronics, such as bookcases and TVs, so they cannot be pulled down on top of the baby. * Using protective padding to cover sharp edges and corners, such as from a coffee table or fireplace hearth. * Installing safety gates at the bottom and top of stairwells or to block entry to unsafe rooms. * Using safety latches on cabinets and doors. * Storing all medicines, cleaning products, and other poisons out of the baby's reach. * Removing rubber tips from doorstops or replace with one-piece doorstops. * Looking for and removing all small objects. Objects that easily can pass through the center of a toilet paper roll might cause choking. * Keeping houseplants out of the baby's reach. Some plants can poison or make your babies sick. * Setting the water heater temperature to no higher than 125 degrees Fahrenheit. Water that is hotter can cause bad burns. * Closely supervising the baby around pets. Even family pets have been know to harm familiar children.<ref name=NIH2017/>
==Furniture== Toddlers typically enjoy [[climbing]] up things with steps. This includes [[furniture]]. Heavy furniture in the home is often not secured to the wall. These pieces of furniture can include [[bookcase]]s and [[dressing table|dressers]] that can weigh hundreds of pounds. Heavy objects like televisions that are on the furniture can also fall onto the child. If the toddler climbs up the furniture it is likely to fall onto the child. This has resulted in the deaths and injuries of children. Even if the children appears uninjured, it is possible that [[internal injuries]] have occurred with serious consequences. Often these injuries are not apparent to caregivers and as a consequence treatment can be delayed. Serious head injuries have also occurred.<ref name = aapfurn/>
Caregivers can prevent accidents related to furniture by securring the furniture to the wall. Placing heavier objects into the lowest drawers. Not placing toys on top of the furniture. Constantly monitoring the activities of the toddler. Putting drawer stops onto the drawers to prevent the toddler from opening the drawer. Mount flat-screen televisions out-of-reach and onto the wall.<ref name = aapfurn/>
==Lead poisoning== {{See|Lead poisoning}} No safe levels of lead in the body of a child is considered safe and can cause problems for the rest of their life.<ref name=CDC2012>{{cite web|title=Advisory Committee On Childhood Lead Poisoning Prevention (ACCLPP)|url=https://www.cdc.gov/nceh/lead/ACCLPP/acclpp_main.htm|publisher=CDC|accessdate=18 May 2012|date=May 2012}}</ref> Children living in low-income families are more likely to have levels of lead in their bodies. Questions regarding the testing procedures have been called into question.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.aap.org/en-us/about-the-aap/aap-press-room/Pages/Study-Improvement-Needed-to-Accurately-Detect-Precise-Levels-of-Lead-in-Blood.aspx | title=Study: Improvement Needed to Accurately Detect Precise Levels of Lead in Blood}}</ref> Children are at greater risk as they are more likely to put objects in their mouth such as those that contain [[lead paint]] and absorb a greater proportion of the lead that they eat.<ref name=WHO2016>{{cite web|title=Lead poisoning and health|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs379/en/|website=WHO|accessdate=14 October 2016|date=September 2016}}</ref> Treatment is available but prevention is better.<ref name=Dap2014/><ref>{{cite web|title=What Do Parents Need to Know to Protect Their Children?|url=https://www.cdc.gov/nceh/lead/acclpp/blood_lead_levels.htm|website=CDC|accessdate=14 October 2016|date=30 October 2012}}</ref><ref name=Gra2007>{{cite journal|last1=Gracia|first1=RC|last2=Snodgrass|first2=WR|title=Lead toxicity and chelation therapy.|journal=American Journal of Health-System Pharmacy|date=1 January 2007|volume=64|issue=1|pages=45–53|pmid=17189579|doi=10.2146/ajhp060175}}</ref><ref name=Dap2014>{{cite journal|last1=Dapul|first1=H|last2=Laraque|first2=D|title=Lead poisoning in children.|journal=Advances in Pediatrics|date=August 2014|volume=61|issue=1|pages=313–33|pmid=25037135|doi=10.1016/j.yapd.2014.04.004 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0065310114000164}}<sup>subscription required</sup></ref>
==Sleep== Bumper pads installed in [[Infant bed|crib]]s have been improved so that an infant cannot get caught between the pad and the bars of the crib.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.google.com/patents/US6564403 | title=Baby bumper pad}}</ref>
==Infant and toddler food safety== {{Main|Infant food safety}} Infant food safety is the identification of risky food handling practices and the prevention of illness in infants. The most simple and easiest to implement is handwashing.<ref name = fsgov>{{cite web|url=https://www.foodsafety.gov/keep/types/babyfood/index.html|title=Baby Food and Infant Formula|last=Foodsafety.gov|website=www.foodsafety.gov|accessdate=26 July 2017}}{{PD-notice}}</ref><ref name = FDA2017>{{cite web|url=https://www.fda.gov/Food/ResourcesForYou/HealthEducators/ucm089629.htm|title=Health Educators - Food Safety for Moms to Be: Once Baby Arrives|first=Center for Food Safety and Applied|last=Nutrition|website=www.fda.gov|accessdate=25 July 2017}}{{PD-notice}}</ref> Food for young children, including formula and [[baby food]] can contain pathogens that can make the child very ill and even die.<ref name = form>{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/features/cronobacter/index.html|title=Learn About Cronobacter|publisher=|accessdate=26 July 2017|date=2017-04-10}}{{PD-notice}}</ref><ref>http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/43547/1/9241563311_eng.pdf?ua=1 page xv</ref><ref name="FDA2017"/>
==Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)== {{Main | Sudden infant death syndrome}} Sudden infant death syndrome can cause the death of an infant and often no cause is found. There are some preventative measures that can be taken to reduce the risk of SIDS. These are: * Lay the infant on his back for sleeping.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pease|first1=AS|last2=Fleming|first2=PJ|last3=Hauck|first3=FR|last4=Moon|first4=RY|last5=Horne|first5=RS|last6=L'Hoir|first6=MP|last7=Ponsonby|first7=AL|last8=Blair|first8=PS|title=Swaddling and the Risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome: A Meta-analysis.|journal=Pediatrics|date=June 2016|volume=137|issue=6|doi=10.1542/peds.2015-3275|pmid=27244847|quote=Limited evidence suggested swaddling risk increased with infant age and was associated with a twofold risk for infants aged >6 months.|page=e20153275}}</ref><ref name=Mitch2009>{{cite journal | author = Mitchell EA | title = SIDS: past, present and future. | journal = Acta Paediatrica | volume = 98 | issue = 11 | pages = 1712–9 | date = November 2009 | pmid = 19807704 | doi = 10.1111/j.1651-2227.2009.01503.x }}</ref> * [[Breastfeeding]]<ref name="What Can Be Done">{{cite web |title=What Can Be Done? |publisher=American SIDS Institute |url=http://www.sids.org/nprevent.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030621224728/http://www.sids.org/nprevent.htm |archivedate=2003-06-21 |df= }}</ref> * Keeping the mattress free of all objects and instead dress the infant warmly.<ref name="What Can Be Done"/><ref name="aap_sacks">{{cite web |title=The Changing Concept of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome: Diagnostic Coding Shifts, Controversies Regarding the Sleeping Environment, and New Variables to Consider in Reducing Risk |publisher=[[American Academy of Pediatrics]] |accessdate=2008-11-06 |url=http://aappolicy.aappublications.org/cgi/content/full/pediatrics;116/5/1245#SEC15}}</ref> * Immunizations.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Müller-Nordhorn|first1=Jacqueline|last2=Hettler-Chen|first2=Chih-Mei|last3=Keil|first3=Thomas|last4=Muckelbauer|first4=Rebecca|title=Association between sudden infant death syndrome and diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis immunisation: an ecological study|journal=BMC Pediatrics|date=28 January 2015|volume=15|issue=1|pages=1|doi=10.1186/s12887-015-0318-7|pmid=25626628|pmc=4326294}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mitchell|first1=E A|last2=Stewart|first2=A W|last3=Clements|first3=M|title=Immunisation and the sudden infant death syndrome. New Zealand Cot Death Study Group.|journal=Archives of Disease in Childhood|date=1 December 1995|volume=73|issue=6|pages=498–501|doi=10.1136/adc.73.6.498|pmid=8546503|pmc=1511439}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Fleming|first1=P. J|title=The UK accelerated immunisation programme and sudden unexpected death in infancy: case-control study|journal=BMJ|date=7 April 2001|volume=322|issue=7290|pages=822|doi=10.1136/bmj.322.7290.822|pmid=11290634|pmc=30557}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Do immunisations reduce the risk for SIDS? A meta-analysis|first=M.M.T. |last=Vennemann |first2=M. |last2=Höffgen |first3=T. |last3=Bajanowski |first4=H.-W. |last4=Hense |first5=E.A. |last5=Mitchell|journal=Vaccine|volume=25|issue=26|pages=4875–9|date=2007|doi=10.1016/j.vaccine.2007.02.077 |pmid=17400342}}</ref><!--<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hoffman|first1=HJ|last2=Hunter|first2=JC|last3=Damus|first3=K|last4=Pakter|first4=J|last5=Peterson|first5=DR|last6=van Belle|first6=G|last7=Hasselmeyer|first7=EG|title=Diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis immunization and sudden infant death: results of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development Cooperative Epidemiological Study of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome risk factors.|journal=Pediatrics|date=April 1987|volume=79|issue=4|pages=598–611|pmid=3493477}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Carvajal|first1=A|last2=Caro-Patón|first2=T|last3=Martín de Diego|first3=I|last4=Martín Arias|first4=LH|last5=Alvarez Requejo|first5=A|last6=Lobato|first6=A|title=[DTP vaccine and infant sudden death syndrome. Meta-analysis].|journal=Medicina clinica|date=4 May 1996|volume=106|issue=17|pages=649–52|pmid=8691909}}</ref>--> * Use a pacifier. * Using a 'sleep sack' which prevents the infant from turning over and sleeping on her stomach.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=L'Hoir MP, Engelberts AC, van Well GT, McClelland S, Westers P, Dandachli T, Mellenbergh GJ, Wolters WH, Huber J | title = Risk and preventive factors for cot death in The Netherlands, a low-incidence country | journal = Eur. J. Pediatr. | volume = 157 | issue = 8 | pages = 681–8 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9727856 | doi = 10.1007/s004310050911 }}</ref>
==Child abuse== {{Main | Child abuse}} It is important that caregivers recognize the potential of the abuse of their infant or toddler. An infant or toddler is potentially vulnerable to [[physical abuse]], [[sexual abuse]], [[psychological abuse]] and [[neglect]] and has inability to verbalize the details of the abuse.<ref name=AIFSWhat>{{cite web |title=What is Child Abuse and Neglect? |publisher=Australian Institute of Family Studies |url=https://aifs.gov.au/cfca/publications/what-child-abuse-and-neglect |date=September 2015}}</ref> [[Child grooming]] can be a concern and occurs when a perpetrator wins the trust of caregivers for the purpose of creating an opportunity for them to sexually abuse an infant or toddler.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pandys.org/articles/sexualabusegrooming.html|title=Child Sexual Abuse and the "Grooming" Process|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="Sanderson">{{cite book|author=Christiane Sanderson|title= Counselling Adult Survivors of Child Sexual Abuse|publisher=[[Jessica Kingsley Publishers]]|isbn=978-1843103356|year=2006|page=30|accessdate=April 6, 2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hpq-SvwKtkUC&pg=PA30}}</ref><!--<ref name="O'Donnell">{{cite book |author=Ian O'Donnell |author2=Claire Milner |title=Child Pornography: Crime, Computers and Society |publisher=[[Routledge]] |isbn=1135846286 |year=2012 |page=59|accessdate=April 6, 2016 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G2sQBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA59}}</ref><ref name="Moore">{{cite book |author=Robert Moore |title=Cybercrime: Investigating High-Technology Computer Crime |publisher=[[Routledge]] |isbn=1317522974|year=2014|page=86|accessdate=April 6, 2016 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fyqgBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA86}}</ref>--> [[Shaken baby syndrome]] can often result in serious and permanent brain damage to an infant or toddler.<ref name=Ad2014>{{cite book|title=Advanced Pediatric Assessment, Second Edition|date=2014|publisher=Springer Publishing Company|isbn=9780826161765|page=484|edition=2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LbvxBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA484|language=en}}</ref><ref name="Miehl">{{Cite web|url=http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/515880|title=Shaken Baby Syndrome | accessdate=2011-04-27 | publisher=[[Journal of Forensic Nursing]] }}</ref> There are preventative measures that can be taken to reduce the risk of injuring a child this way. Those who care for infants and toddlers may benefit from stress reduction. Becoming educated on normal child development can help someone understand that crying is a normal thing for babies and toddlers, especially if they hungry or need a diaper change. Caregivers can contact another person who is willing to give them a break. Those who are drinking alcohol are more likely to injure the infant or toddler. Carefully choosing someone else to watch the infant or toddler can also reduce the risk of injury.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.healthychildren.org/English/safety-prevention/at-home/Pages/Abusive-Head-Trauma-Shaken-Baby-Syndrome.aspx | title=Abusive Head Trauma: How to Protect Your Baby}}</ref>
==Car accidents== {{See|Child safety seat}} Children under the age of 3 were 43% are less likely to be injured in a car crash if their car seat was placed in the center of the car. The center position is the safest but the least used position.<ref name=Levitt>[http://www.ted.com/talks/steven_levitt_on_child_carseats.html Lecture by Levitt at TED] Retrieved June 2011</ref>
==Hyperthermia and hypothermia== [[File:Icy pond in Struie Wood - geograph.org.uk - 1055578.jpg|thumb|Even a very small icy pond can be hazardous for a toddler]] Forgetting that an infant or toddler is in the car and leaving them where they are exposed to high temperatures can result in death.<ref>{{cite news |date=March 26, 2009 |title=The Last Word: Forgotten Baby Syndrome |journal=The Week |url=http://www.theweek.com/article/index/94741/The_last_word_Forgotten_baby_syndrome}}</ref>
Toddlers can wander off and fall through ice or be left out in cool or cold weather and experience hypothermia. This low body temperature is often fatal but instances of survival after a near drowning occur.Of all drowning deaths in 2013, 82,000 occurred in children less than five years old.<ref name=GDB2013>{{cite journal|last1=GBD 2013 Mortality and Causes of Death|first1=Collaborators|title=Global, regional, and national age-sex specific all-cause and cause-specific mortality for 240 causes of death, 1990-2013: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2013 |journal=Lancet|date=17 December 2014 |pmid=25530442 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(14)61682-2 |pmc=4340604 |volume=385 |issue=9963|pages=117–71}}</ref>
==Drowning== Toddlers have wandered off and drowned in ponds.<ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.thestate.com/news/local/article160945674.html | title=2-year-old drowns in pond inside SC community}}</ref> Toddlers can easily drown in small, shallow ornamental ponds.<ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.lehighvalleylive.com/news/index.ssf/2017/06/toddler_dies_after_being_found.html | title=Toddler dies after being found in Pa. Pond, authorities say}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url=http://fox40.com/2017/07/05/babysitter-of-toddler-found-in-koi-pond-to-be-arraigned/ | title=Babysitter of Toddler Found in Koi Pond to be Arraigned| date=2017-07-05}}</ref> [[File:Five gallon bucket 20080716.jpg|thumb|left|This five gallon bucket comes with a warning that it can be filled with fluid and an infant can drown.]]
==Animal attacks== {{See|Dog bite prevention}} An infant or toddler is more likely than other family members to be injured by an animal because they cannot defend themselves and are lower to the ground. Familiar family pets with no prior history of aggression are more likely to attack the child than unfamiliar pets from other households.
==Choking== Toddlers and infants who can hold objects can choke when a small object is inhaled and blocks the trachea.
Babywipes (diaper wipes) can be a choke hazard
==Falls== Even high chairs are hazardout<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://consumer.healthday.com/general-health-information-16/emergencies-and-first-aid-news-227/rise-in-u-s-high-chair-injuries-stuns-experts-682889.html | title=Rise in U.S. High Chair Injuries Stuns Experts}}</ref>
==External links== * [http://www.vachss.com/guest_dispatches/grooming.html Grooming Children for Sexual Molestation], written by Gregory M. Weber, the Assistant Attorney General for the State of Wisconsin who specializes in the prosecution of crimes committed against children. *[http://www.nsc.org/NSCDocuments_Advocacy/Fact%20Sheets/Infant-Safety.pdf Baby-Proofing Your Home]. Guidelines from the [[National Safety Council]]
==References== {{reflist}}
