revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=March 2016}} [[File:Tom headshot.jpg|thumbnail]] '''Thomas J. Coates''' (born 1945) is the Director of the multi-campus University of California Global Health Institute,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ucghi.universityofcalifornia.edu/about-us/bios/coates-thomas.aspx|title=Thomas J. Coates, PhD {{!}} Bios {{!}} About Us - UC Global Health Institute|website=www.ucghi.universityofcalifornia.edu|access-date=2016-02-26}}</ref> a UC-wide initiative established to improve health and reduce the burden of disease throughout the world. He is Professor Emeritus at the UCLA David Geffen School of Medicine and Founding Director of the UCLA Center for World Health,<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0140673614605353|title = Offline: America—a country facing two futures|last = Horton|first = Richard|date = 25 April 2014|journal = The Lancet|doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(14)60535-3|pmid = |access-date = 5 January 2016|issue = 9927|pages = 1448|volume = 383}}</ref> a joint initiative of the David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA and UCLA Health, He has conducted extensive research in the realm of HIV<ref name=":0">{{Cite web | url = https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=zSAucdEAAAAJ&hl=en | title = Thomas J. Coates, PhD - Google Scholar Citations | website = scholar.google.com | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref> and is the Michael and Sue Steinberg Endowed Professor of Global AIDS Research within the Division of Infectious Diseases at UCLA and Distinguished Professor of Medicine.<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.apo.ucla.edu/academic-listings/endowed-chairs/#The%2520David%2520Geffen%2520School%2520of%2520Medicine | title = UCLA Academic Personnel Office | website = www.apo.ucla.edu | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref> Health-related behavior is of particular interest to Coates. Throughout his career as a health expert, his theory-based research has been focused on interventions aimed at reducing risks and threats to health<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.kcrw.com/people/tom-coates | title = Tom Coates — KCRW | website = www.kcrw.com | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref>
== Education == Coates studied at San Luis Rey College and obtained his BA in Philosophy in 1968. He attended San Jose State University from 1968 to 1971, receiving his Master's in Psychology. He also completed his PhD in Counseling Psychology at Stanford University in 1977.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://worldhealth.med.ucla.edu/index.php/about/people/thomasjcoates/ | title = Thomas J. Coates, PhD {{!}} UCLA Center for World Health | website = UCLA Center for World Health | language = en-US | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref>
== Career == Coates joined the Department of Psychiatry at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine with a joint appointment in the Bloomberg School of Public Health in 1979 and served on the Faculty at Johns Hopkins until 1982.
In 1982, the University of California San Francisco, School of Medicine appointed him faculty of the Department of Medicine, Division of Primary Care Internal Medicine.
In 1986, during the height of the HIV epidemic and fueled by his passion for infectious disease research, Coates co-founded the Center for AIDS Prevention Studies at UCSF, directing it from 1991 to 2003.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://ari.ucsf.edu/about-us/history-aids-ucsf | title = The History of AIDS at UCSF {{!}} AIDS Research Institute | website = ari.ucsf.edu | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref> In 1996, coordinating and integrating all of UCSF's AIDS research activities under an umbrella of 60 programs and laboratories,<ref>{{Cite web|title = AIDS Expert Tom Coates Leaves UCSF AIDS Research Institute for UCLA|url = http://khn.org/morning-breakout/dr00018003|website = Kaiser Health News|access-date = 2016-02-09|language = en-US}}</ref> Coates founded the AIDS Research Institute, and was its Executive Director until 2003.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.sfgate.com/health/article/UCSF-loses-man-who-shaped-AIDS-Research-Institute-2614424.php|title = UCSF loses man who shaped AIDS Research Institute / Coates follows partner to UCLA|date = 29 May 2003|access-date = 5 January 2016|website = San Francisco Chronicle|publisher = SFGATE|last = Russell|first = Sabin}}</ref> As a leading behavioral scientist, Coates made great strides in behavioral research in HIV primary and secondary prevention both domestically and globally and conducted HIV research on three continents.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Feds Spent $800,000 of Economic Stimulus on African Genital-Washing Program|url = http://www.cnsnews.com/news/article/feds-spent-800000-economic-stimulus-african-genital-washing-program-0|website = CNS News|access-date = 2016-02-09}}</ref> With funding from USAID and WHO, Coates led a randomized control trial to determine the efficacy of HIV voluntary counseling and testing in Kenya, Trinidad, and Tanzania.<ref>{{Cite journal | date = 2000-07-08 | title = Efficacy of voluntary HIV-1 counselling and testing in individuals and couples in Kenya, Tanzania, and Trinidad: a randomised trial. The Voluntary HIV-1 Counseling and Testing Efficacy Study Group | journal = Lancet | volume = 356 | issue = 9224 | pages = 103–112 | issn = 0140-6736 | pmid = 10963246 | doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(00)02446-6 }}</ref> As the principal investigator for Project Accept (HPTN 043), Coates led a study on the effect of community-based voluntary counseling and testing on HIV incidence in a cluster-randomized trial in 48 communities at five sites in South Africa, Tanzania, Zimbabwe, and Thailand.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.cbvct.med.ucla.edu/ | title = Project Accept (HPTN 043): A Cluster-Randomized Trial of Community Mobilization, Mobile HIV Testing, Post-Test Support Services, and Real-Time Performance Feedback | website = www.cbvct.med.ucla.edu | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref> He also led a prevention clinical trial in South America. In 2000, he was elected as a member of the Institute of Medicine.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web | url = http://iom.nationalacademies.org/Global/Directory/Member%20Detail.aspx?id=0000012666 | title = National Academy of Medicine Directory | last = | first = | date = | website = National Academy of Medicine | publisher = National Academy of Medicine | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref>
Coates' studies on the pivotal role of behavioral science in combating the HIV/AIDS epidemic have been a catalyst for social change.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.apa.org/monitor/nov02/hiv.aspx | title = 'HIV needs psychology' | website = American Psychological Association | access-date = 2016-02-09 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = National Research Council (US) Committee on National Needs for Biomedical and Behavioral Scientists.|last = |first = |publisher = National Academies Press (US)|year = 2000|location = Washington (DC)|pages = Appendix F, Personal Statement Concerning Research Training in the Behavioral and Social Sciences.|url = https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK208967/|work = Addressing the Nation's Changing Needs for Biomedical and Behavioral Scientists.|doi = 10.17226/9827}}</ref> In 2013, Coates received the Elizabeth Fries Health Education Award in appreciation of his pioneering HIV-related research and to honor his contributions to public health.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web | url = http://www.sophe.org/Awards2013PressRelease.cfm | title = Society for Public Health Education | website = www.sophe.org | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref>
Aside from HIV prevention, Coates' areas of emphasis are centered on global health and international health policy.<ref name=":0" />
== Honors and awards == * 2015 Unsung Hero Award, Blood:Water, Nashville, Tennessee<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://event.bloodwater.org/redtiegala/ | title = Blood Water Red Tie Gala | website = event.bloodwater.org | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref> * 2013 The Elizabeth Fries Health Education Award/Society of Public Health Education<ref name=":2" /> * 2004 Award for Distinguished Contribution to Research in the Public Policy, American Psychological Association, Washington, DC<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.apa.org/about/awards/public-policy.aspx | title = Award for Distinguished Contributions to Research in Public Policy {{!}} BAPPI | website = American Psychological Association | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref> * 2000 Elected to the Institute of Medicine (now the National Academy of Medicine) of the National Academy of Sciences<ref name=":1" /> * 1996 Stop AIDS Project, Sam B. Puckett Memorial HIV Prevention Award, for leadership and dedication in the fight against AIDS<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/BAY-AREA-REPORT-SAN-FRANCISCO-STOP-AIDS-2973375.php | title = BAY AREA REPORT -- SAN FRANCISCO / STOP AIDS Project Honors 3 Activists | website = SFGate | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref> * 1994 Centers for Disease Control, Charles C. Shepard Science Award, for program participation and presentation, "HIV Prevention Programs in Research: What Have We Accomplished and Where Do We Need to Go?"<ref>"Ending the HIV/AIDS Pandemic: From Scientific Advances to Public Health Implementation. 2015 Charles C. Shepard Science Awards". ''U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Centers for Disease Control and Prevention''. 18 June 2015. pp. 57. [https://www.cdc.gov/od/science/aboutus/shepard/images/SSA15_Program.pdf https://www.cdc.gov/od/science/aboutus/shepard/images/SSA15_Program.pdf.]</ref> * 1991 American Psychological Association, Division of Health Psychology Award, for outstanding contribution to health psychology<ref>{{Cite web |url = http://www.health-psych.org/AwardsHistory.cfm |title = APA Division 38: Awards History |website = www.health-psych.org |access-date = 2016-02-26 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160303210812/http://www.health-psych.org/AwardsHistory.cfm |archivedate = 2016-03-03 |df = }}</ref>
==References== <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Coates, Thomas J.}} [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:San Jose State University alumni]] [[Category:Stanford University alumni]] [[Category:People in public health]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS researchers]]

revision.comment: /* Themes */
revision.text:
{{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = World Malaria Day |type = international |longtype = |image = World Health Organization Flag.jpg |caption = |official_name = |nickname = |observedby = All Member States of the [[World Health Organization]] |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual |scheduling = same day each year |date = April 25 |celebrations = |relatedto = }}
'''World Malaria Day''' ('''WMD''') is an [[international observance]] commemorated every year on 25 April and recognizes global efforts to control [[malaria]]. Globally, 3.3 billion people in 106 countries are at risk of malaria.<ref name=WHO2010>World Health Organization,[http://www.who.int/malaria/world_malaria_report_2010/en/index.html ''World Malaria Report 2010''.]</ref> In 2012, malaria caused an estimated 627,000 deaths, mostly among African children.<ref>World Health Organization, [http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs094/en/ Malaria.] WHO Fact sheet N°94, updated March 2014. Accessed 8 April 2014.</ref> Asia, Latin America, and to a lesser extent the Middle East and parts of Europe are also affected.
World Malaria Day sprung out of the efforts taking place across the African continent to commemorate '''Africa Malaria Day'''. WMD is one of eight official [[global health|global public health]] campaigns currently marked by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO), along with [[World Health Day]], [[World Blood Donor Day]], [[World Immunization Week]], [[World Tuberculosis Day]], [[World No Tobacco Day]], [[World Hepatitis Day]] and [[World AIDS Day]].<ref>World Health Organization, [http://www.who.int/campaigns/en WHO campaigns.]</ref>
According to the most recent World Malaria Report, the global tally of malaria reached 429,000 malaria deaths and 212 million new cases in 2015. The rate of new malaria cases fell by 21 per cent globally between 2010 and 2015, and malaria death rates fell by 29 per cent in the same period. In sub-Saharan Africa, case incidence and death rates fell by 21 per cent and 31 per cent, respectively.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jatinder|first1=Kaur|title=World Malaria Day Asks Malaria Prevention|url=http://abclive.in/world-malaria-day-malaria-prevention/|accessdate=30 April 2017|agency=ABC Live|issue=Online|publisher=ABC Live}}</ref>
==History== '''World Malaria Day''' was established in May 2007 by the 60th session of the [[World Health Assembly]], WHO's decision-making body. The day was established to provide "education and understanding of malaria" and spread information on "year-long intensified implementation of national malaria-control strategies, including community-based activities for malaria prevention and treatment in endemic areas."<ref>[http://www.who.int/gb/ebwha/pdf_files/WHA60/A60_R18-en.pdf WHA Resolution 60.18]</ref>
Prior to the establishment of WMD, '''Africa Malaria Day'''<ref>[http://www.rollbackmalaria.org/globaladvocacy/africamalariaday.html Africa Malaria Days 2001-2007]</ref> was held on April 25. Africa Malaria Day began in 2001, one year after the historic ''Abuja Declaration''<ref>African Summit on Roll Back Malaria, [http://www.rollbackmalaria.org/docs/abuja_declaration_final.htm Abuja Declaration.] Abuja, 25 April 2000.</ref> was signed by 44 malaria-endemic countries at the African Summit on Malaria.<ref>[http://www.rollbackmalaria.org/globaladvocacy/africansummit2000.html African Malaria Summit]</ref>
World Malaria Day allows for corporations (such as [[ExxonMobil]]<ref>ExxonMobil, [http://www.exxonmobil.com/Corporate/community_malaria_wmd.aspx Commemorating World Malaria Day 2013.]</ref>), multinational organizations (such as [[Malaria No More]]<ref>Malaria No More UK, [http://malarianomore.org.uk/world-malaria-day World Malaria Day.]</ref>) and grassroots organizations (such as [[Mosquitoes Suck Tour]]<ref>http://dontbiteme.ca/more-about-malaria/</ref>) globally to work together to bring [[awareness]] to malaria and advocate for [[health policy|policy]] changes.<ref>Malaria Community, [http://www.worldmalariaday.org/about_the_site_en.cfm World Malaria Day.]</ref>
==Themes== Each World Malaria Day focuses on a specific theme. Current and past themes include the following: *World Malaria Day 2018: "Ready to beat malaria" *World Malaria Day 2016-2017: "End Malaria For Good"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://globalhealthstrategies.com/blog/impact/world-malaria-day-2017/|title=World Malaria Day 2017 - Global Health Strategies|work=Global Health Strategies|access-date=2018-01-13|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.afro.who.int/media-centre/events/world-malaria-day-2017-end-malaria-good|title=World Malaria Day 2017: End malaria for good|website=WHO {{!}} Regional Office for Africa|language=en|access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/campaigns/malaria-day/2016/event/en/|title=World Malaria Day 2016: End malaria for good|website=World Health Organization|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> *World Malaria Day 2013-2014-2015: "Invest in the future: defeat malaria"<ref>[http://www.rollbackmalaria.org/worldmalariaday/index.html World Malaria Day 2013-2015 web site]</ref> *World Malaria Day 2012: "Sustain Gains, Save Lives: Invest in Malaria"<ref>[http://www.rollbackmalaria.org/worldmalariaday20412/index.html World Malaria Day 2012 web site]</ref> *World Malaria Day 2011: "Achieving Progress and Impact"<ref>[http://www.rollbackmalaria.org/worldmalariaday20011/index.html World Malaria Day 2011 web site]</ref> *World Malaria Day 2009-2010: "Counting malaria out"<ref>[http://www.rollbackmalaria.org/worldmalariaday2010/index.html World Malaria Day 2009-2010 web site]</ref> *World Malaria Day 2008: "Malaria: a disease without borders"<ref>[http://www.rollbackmalaria.org/worldmalariaday2008/index.html World Malaria Day 2008 web site]</ref>
==Global Events== ===Europe=== Leading to World Malaria Day 2014, the European Vaccine Initiative announced sixteen new projects for the acceleration of malaria vaccine development.<ref>European Vaccine Initiative. [http://www.euvaccine.eu/sites/default/files/uploads/docs/news/EVI_WMD-PR_final_140415.pdf World Malaria Day 2014: New vaccine candidates against malaria enter clinical development.] 22 April 2014. Accessed 7 October 2014.</ref> The projects were to be undertaken by an international consortium involving partners from the public and private sectors from Europe, USA and Africa.
===India=== For World Malaria Day 2017, efforts across India included a series of measures to control the spread of this vector-borne disease. The coastal city of Mangaluru identified open water resources to target for eliminating mosquitos that spread malaria.<ref>Times of India, [http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mangaluru/world-malaria-day-statistics-indicate-dip-in-mangaluru-cases/articleshow/58363738.cms "World Malaria Day: Statistics indicate dip in Mangaluru cases,"] Apr 25, 2017 (accessed Apr 25, 2017).</ref>
===Nigeria=== [[File:Mosquito Netting.jpg|thumb|Ceiling hung mosquito netting.]] Events marking World Malaria Day 2014 in Nigeria included a demonstration of [[anti-malarial bed net]]s, testing and distribution of anti-malarial drugs, seminars on progress in combating and controlling malaria, and the inclusion of African footballers in the campaign to combat malaria.<ref>Federal Ministry of Health. [http://www.nmcp.gov.ng/World-Malaria-Day-2014 Are You Ready for World Malaria Day 2014?] Abuja, 11 April 2014. Accessed 7 October 2014.</ref>
As of 2016, the Federal Ministry of Health has pledged to end Malaria.<ref>[http://www.nmcp.gov.ng/ "Home"]</ref> The U.S. Ambassador to Nigeria, James F. Entwistle, has pledged continued support and noted the possibility of ending Malaria in Nigeria.<ref>[https://nigeria.usembassy.gov/oped_04252016.html "Opinion Editorial"]</ref>
===United States=== [[Image:George W. Bush delivers remarks on Malaria Awareness Day 2007.jpg|thumb|President Bush addresses Americans in The White House Rose Garden about the issues of malaria]] April 25 was designated as ''Malaria Awareness Day'' in 2007 by President [[George W. Bush]], who called on Americans to join in on the goal to eradicate malaria on the African continent.<ref name="GB">George W. Bush. The White House: Office of the Press Secretary. [https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2007/04/20070424-11.html Malaria Awareness Day, 2007.] 24 April 2007.</ref> President Bush described it as a day when "we focus our attention on all who suffer from this terrible disease -- especially the millions on the continent of Africa. We remember the millions more who died from this entirely preventable and treatable disease." President Bush shared the White House's strategic plan against malaria, which included endeavors to distribute bed nets with the New York-based nonprofit group [[Malaria No More]].<ref name="WH">The White House: Office of the Press Secretary. [https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2007/04/20070425-2.html President Bush and Mrs. Bush Discuss Malaria Awareness Day.] 25 April 2007.</ref>
Other former U.S. Presidents are involved in anti-malaria efforts. Former President [[Bill Clinton]]'s [[Clinton Foundation]] includes an anti-malaria component that, according to director [[Inder Singh (philanthropist)|Inder Singh]] has distributed anti-malaria drugs to millions in Africa and Asia.<ref name="MIT">[http://hst.mit.edu/servlet/ControllerServlet?handler=PublicHandler&action=browse&pageId=2261 BEP grad Inder Singh orchestrates affordable malaria drug development], Harvard-MIT Health Sciences.</ref>
Many prominent companies, organizations, and celebrities have declared initiatives to join the fight against malaria to mark this day. These include a $3 million "challenge grant" announced by [[ExxonMobil]] to match donations dollar by dollar to [[Malaria No More]], as part of the "[[Idol Gives Back]]" episodes of [[American Idol]], which was aired on Malaria Awareness Day. [[Major League Soccer]] Commissioner [[Don Garber]] also announced that the league would promote malaria awareness and bed net fundraising promotions in the month of April leading up to Malaria Awareness Day. Actress [[Ashley Judd]], announced the April launch of a new initiative called “5 & Alive,” which will focus on the devastating effects of malaria on children under 5. The [[Boys & Girls Clubs of America]] announced their own national campaign called "Malaria Prevention: Deadly Disease. Simple Solution", which will partner with Malaria No More to approach all 4.7 Million Club members worldwide to ask for $10 bed net donations.<ref name="MNM">Malaria No More. [http://www.malarianomore.org/media/malarianomore-mad-32907.pdf Run up to April 25, the First Malaria Awareness Day in the US.] 29 March 2007.</ref>
The movement is not without its critics, such as the African economist [[Dambisa Moyo]] who warns that the short term benefits of aid such as mosquito nets can have long term detrimental effects to the sustainability of African economies. When the markets are flooded with foreign nets then this puts African entrepreneurs out of business.{{citation needed|date=October 2014}}
